page.title: LGBT rights protests surrounding the 2014 Winter Olympics

revision.comment: Bot: [[User:KolbertBot|HTTP→HTTPS]] (v485)
revision.text:
{{2014 Winter Olympics}} During the lead-up to the [[2014 Winter Olympics]], protests and campaigns arose surrounding the [[LGBT rights|rights]] of [[lesbian]], [[gay]], [[bisexual]], and [[transgender]] ([[LGBT]]) people [[LGBT rights in Russia |in Russia]].
Concerns for LGBT athletes and supporters during the Games began as early as March 2012, when a Russian judge blocked the establishment of a [[Pride House]] in [[Sochi]], ruling that "propaganda of non-traditional sexual relationships" would "undermine the security of Russian society", and that it conflicted with [[public morality]] and the country's policies "in the area of family motherhood and childhood protection."<ref name=itg-nopridehouse>{{cite web |title=Judge bans Sochi 2014 gay Pride House claiming it would offend "public morality" |url= http://www.insidethegames.biz/olympics/winter-olympics/2014/16259-judge-bans-winter-olympics-gay-pride-house |work=Inside the Games |accessdate=12 February 2014}}</ref> The majority of protests, however, centred on the passing of a law in June 2013, which [[Russian LGBT propaganda law |banned]] the distribution of "propaganda of non-traditional sexual relationships" among minors. The propaganda law had been characterized by the Western media and other critics as a ban on "gay propaganda", arguing that it was broad enough to ban any public display of [[LGBT symbols]] and suppress [[LGBT culture]]. The law itself was also considered to have caused an increase in homophobic violence, and an increase in the arrest of pro-LGBT protesters.<ref name=nyt-nohaven>{{cite news |title=Gays in Russia Find No Haven, Despite Support From the West |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2013/08/12/world/europe/gays-in-russia-find-no-haven-despite-support-from-the-west.html |work=The New York Times |accessdate=10 February 2014 |first=David M. |last=Herszenhorn |date=2013-08-11}}</ref><ref name="variety-gaychallenge">{{cite news |last=Johnson |first=Ted |title=Russia's Anti-Gay Laws Present Challenge for NBC's Olympics Coverage |url= https://variety.com/2013/tv/news/russia-7-1200567694/ |accessdate=25 July 2013 |newspaper=Variety |date=24 July 2013}}</ref><ref name="nyt-crackdown">{{cite news |last=Fierstein |first=Harvey |title=Russia's Anti-Gay Crackdown |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/22/opinion/russias-anti-gay-crackdown.html?_r=0 |accessdate=25 July 2013 |newspaper=The New York Times |date=21 July 2013}}</ref><ref name=homophobicviolence>{{cite news |last=Luhn |first=Alec |title=Russian anti-gay law prompts rise in homophobic violence |url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/sep/01/russia-rise-homophobic-violence |newspaper=The Guardian |date=1 September 2013}}</ref><ref name=fthomophobicviolence>{{cite news |last=Weaver |first=Courtney |title=Russia gay propaganda law fuels homophobic attacks |newspaper=Financial Times |date=16 August 2013}}</ref>
The implications of the law on the then-upcoming Winter Olympics were a major concern among athletes and the Western media, as the [[Olympic Charter]] contains language explicitly denouncing all forms of [[discrimination]]. Early international pressure was leveraged to compel the [[International Olympic Committee]] (IOC) to move the Olympics to another country, as well as pressure on Olympic sponsors to take a stand for LGBT equality. In tandem, calls to boycott and protest the Olympics before, during, and after the games also went out from various organizations and groups, and a number of Olympic athletes [[Coming out|came out]] as a symbolic protest of the law. Prior to the Games, similar pressure was placed on major Olympic sponsors, and several non-sponsors also made public statements in support of LGBT rights. Several national politicians declined to attend the Games, which some Western media outlets attributed as connected to the legislation, while others stated that few leaders normally attend the Winter Games as it is not a "must attend" event.
==Timeline of protests and related events==
===2013=== * (June 2013) Russia passes a law with near unanimous support by Russian lawmakers, and signed by President Vladimir Putin, banning the "propaganda of nontraditional sexual relations", and "imposes fines for providing information about the gay community to minors."<ref name="bigstory.ap.org">{{cite web|last=Crary |first=David |url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/foes-russias-anti-gay-law-ponder-new-tactics |title=Foes of Russia's Anti-Gay Law Ponder New Tactics |publisher=Bigstory.ap.org |date= |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> * (29 June 2013) Dozens of gay activists were beaten and arrested at a [[gay rights]] rally in St. Petersburg citing the new law.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.ria.ru/russia/20130629/181953195/Dozens-Held-at-LGBT-Rally-in-Russias-StPetersburg.html |title=Dozens Held at LGBT Rally in Russia's St.Petersburg |publisher=En.ria.ru |date= |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/dozens-arrested-gay-pride-rally-russia |title=Dozens Arrested At Gay Pride Rally In Russia |publisher=Bigstory.ap.org |date= |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> * (July 2013) A multifaceted campaign is launched to raise awareness about the gay rights situation in Russia, and stem future Olympic bids going to countries who violate human rights.<ref name="bigstory.ap.org"/> * (July 23, 2013) The first arrests of foreign citizens under the ban against gay propaganda took place in [[Murmansk]], when four Dutch citizens, attending a human rights seminar, were also filming a documentary on gay life in Russia.<ref>{{cite web|last=Lavers |first=Michael K. |url=http://www.washingtonblade.com/2013/07/22/four-dutch-lgbt-advocates-arrested-in-russia/ |title=4 Dutch LGBT advocates arrested in Russia |publisher=Washingtonblade.com |date=2013-07-22 |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://lenta.ru/news/2013/07/22/nocase/ |title=Задержанных под Мурманском голландцев отпустили без суда |publisher=Lenta.ru |date= |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> * (14 August 2013) U.S. runner [[Nick Symmonds]] became "the first international athlete to denounce Russia's law against "gay propaganda" on the country's soil."<ref name=gusrn>{{cite web|author=Alec Luhn in Moscow |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/aug/14/nick-symmonds-speaks-russia-anti-gay-law |title=US athlete Nick Symmonds speaks out against Russia's LGBT propaganda law in Moscow: Runner dedicates silver medal to gay and lesbian friends at home during world athletics championships |publisher=Theguardian.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> He had just won the silver medal in the 800 m race in Moscow, and dedicated the medal to his gay and lesbian friends and called for LGBT equality.<ref name=gusrn/> * (26 August 2013) Australian snowboarder [[Belle Brockhoff]] came out as [[gay]] to bring attention to Russia's LGBT propaganda law, and for lesbian and gay athletes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.towleroad.com/2013/08/australian-snowboarder-belle-brockhoff-comes-out-as-gay-to-make-statement-about-sochi.html |title=Australian Snowboarder Belle Brockhoff Comes Out As Gay To Make Statement About Sochi |publisher=Towleroad.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> * (29 August 2013) [[Human Rights Campaign]] sent letters to the ten Worldwide sponsors of the International Olympic Committee, [[Dow Chemical]], [[Coca-Cola]], [[General Electric]], [[McDonald's]], [[Procter & Gamble]], [[Panasonic]], [[Samsung]], [[Omega SA|Omega]], [[Visa Inc.]], and [[Atos]], to take steps to stem violence against LGBT people including a clear and unequivocal public position in opposition to anti-LGBT laws, denouncing violence targeted against LGBT people and demanding accountability, asking the IOC to obtain written commitments for the safety of LGBT athletes and attendees, and rejecting future Olympic bids from countries that outlaw support for LGBT equality.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hrc.org/blog/entry/hrc-calls-on-olympic-sponsors-to-condemn-anti-lgbt-law-in-russia-advocate-f |title=HRC Calls on Olympic Sponsors to Condemn Anti-LGBT Law in Russia, Advocate for Equality Worldwide |publisher=Hrc.org |date=2014-02-08 |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> * (5 September 2013) Canadian Olympic speed skater [[Anastasia Bucsis]] publicly [[coming out|came out]] as gay "in response to Russia's anti-gay laws."<ref>{{cite news|author=Kelly Cryderman |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/more-sports/olympic-speed-skater-anastasia-bucsis-so-proud-to-be-gay/article14078121/ |title=Olympic speed skater Anastasia Bucsis ‘so proud to be gay’ |work=The Globe and Mail |date=2013-09-03 |accessdate=2014-02-12 |location=Toronto}}</ref> * (25 September 2013) Two gay rights activists were detained by police officers outside the Sochi Organizing Committee office in downtown Moscow. They had been holding a poster, "Homophobia is Russia's Disgrace" during a protest.<ref name="bigstory.ap.org"/> * (15 December 2013) French President [[François Hollande]] first kissed an male citizen (openly against Russian laws) then joined Germany President [[Joachim Gauck]] and EU Commissioner [[Viviane Reding]] in boycotting the Sochi Olympics in protest of the law.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.towleroad.com/2013/12/french-president-joins-boycott-of-sochi-olympics.html |title=French President Joins Boycott of Sochi Olympics |publisher=Towleroad.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> * (20 December 2013) The U.S. official delegation, in a surprise announcement, would not include any members of President Barack Obama's family, or an active Cabinet secretary, the first time in at least twenty years.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/olympics/2013/12/17/president-obama-sochi-billie-jean-king-winter-games-russia-putin/4058273/ |title=Obama selection of Billie Jean King for Sochi 'genius' |work=USA Today |date=2013-12-17 |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> The delegation instead would be composed of openly gay athletes, "a clear jab at Russia's recent anti-gay laws."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/12/17/sport/us-delegation-russia-olympics/ |title=U.S. delegation to Russian Olympics includes gay athletes |publisher=CNN |date= |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> * (29 December 2013) Olympic gold medalist [[Brian Boitano]] came out as [[gay]] publicly; he had been named as part of the American Olympic Delegation by President [[Barack Obama]]. The actions were widely seen as a response to the anti-gay laws enacted.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/12/19/brian-boitano-comes-out-gay_n_4474418.html |title=Figure Skater Brian Boitano Comes Out As Gay Ahead Of Sochi Olympics |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date= 2013-12-19|accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref>
===2014 (pre-Games)=== * (10 January 2014) The U.S. State Department issued warnings for American traveling to the Olympics. Specifically for LGBT people it noted that "Russia has in place a law that bans the 'propaganda of nontraditional sexual relations' to minors. It said authorities have been vague about defining 'propaganda' and that the law applies to foreigners. A conviction on the charge could result in a fine, a jail term and deportation."<ref>{{cite news|author=Kate Auletta |url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/01/10/sochi-travel-alert_n_4577659.html?ir=Gay%20Voices |title=Sochi Travel Alert: U.S. State Department Issues Warning For Americans During Olympics |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date= 2014-01-10|accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> * (17 January 2014) Russian president [[Vladimir Putin]], in a meeting with Olympic volunteers explained that their rainbow-colored uniforms were not considered violating the Kremlin's anti-LGBT initiatives because "We do not have a ban on non-traditional sexual relationships ... We have a ban on the propaganda of homosexuality and [[paedophilia]]."<ref>{{cite web|author=Shaun Walker in Moscow |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jan/17/vladimir-putin-gay-winter-olympics-children |title=Vladimir Putin: gay people at Winter Olympics must 'leave children alone': Russian president vows no discrimination but says gay people must observe law banning 'homosexual propaganda' |publisher=Theguardian.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> The [[Rainbow flag (LGBT movement) |rainbow flag and colors]] are an international symbol for LGBTQ communities. [[pedophilia and homosexuality |Conflating homosexuality with pedophilia]] has been a common practice in the opposition to the [[LGBT social movements|gay rights movement]]. In its Winter 2010 ''Intelligence Report'' the [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] noted that since the 1980s there has been organized efforts by "hard-line elements of the religious right searching for ways to demonize gay people  — or, at a minimum, to find arguments that will prevent their normalization in society."<ref name=agmyths>{{cite news |title=10 Anti-Gay Myths Debunked |url= http://www.splcenter.org/get-informed/intelligence-report/browse-all-issues/2010/winter/10-myths |accessdate=September 16, 2012 |newspaper=Intelligence Report |date=Winter 2010 |issue=140 |author=Evelyn Schlatter |author2=Robert Steinback}}</ref> These groups utilize anti-gay myths to "form the basis of its claim that homosexuality is a social evil that must be suppressed — an opinion rejected by virtually all relevant medical and scientific authorities."<ref name=agmyths/> The SPLC notes these anti-gay myths "almost certainly contribute to [[hate crime]] violence directed at the LGBT community, which is more targeted for such attacks than any other minority group in America."<ref name=agmyths/> * {{anchor|18Jan}} (18 January 2014) A gay Russian protestor, Pavel Lebedev, was tackled and detained for unfurling a rainbow flag during the Olympic torch relay as it passed through his hometown of Voronezh, 506 miles north of Sochi.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://espn.go.com/olympics/winter/2014/story/_/id/10314120/gay-protester-detained-russia-sochi-olympics-torch-relay |title=Gay protester detained in Russia |publisher=[[ESPN]] |date=2014-01-18 |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> (See [[#23Jan |23 January]].) * {{anchor|23Jan}} (23 January 2014) Olympics sponsor [[McDonald's]] launched a social media campaign ''#CheerstoSochi'' to offer well wishes to Olympians. The [[hashtag]] was quickly hijacked by activists who instead used it to post protest images and messages of support for Pavel Lebedev, who was tackled and detained in his hometown on [[#18Jan |18 January]] for holding a rainbow flag while the Olympic torch went by.<ref>{{cite news |author=Scott Wooledge |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/scott-wooledge/mcdonalds-cheerstosochi-c_b_4640514.html |title=McDonald's #CheersToSochi Campaign Meets With LGBT Backlash |work=Huffington Post |date=2014-01-23 |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> * (27 January 2014) Anatoly Pakhomov, mayor of Sochi, told reporters in January 2014 that homosexuality "was not the custom in the [[Caucasus]]" and claimed that no gays lived in Sochi—despite the presence of two [[gay club]]s and evidence of a LGBT community in Sochi on a Russian social network. He went on to say that everyone, including gays, were welcome in Sochi, "as long as they do not impose their habits on others."<ref name=rtsm>{{cite web |url=http://rt.com/politics/sochi-gays-mayor-claim-240/ |title=Sochi mayor says there are 'no gay people' living in the city |publisher=RT |date=2014-01-27 |accessdate=12 February 2014}}</ref> * (28 January 2014) Olympic sponsor [[Coca-Cola]] was forced to shut down an interactive feature that allowed users to put messages on Coke cans supporting the Olympic athletes. LGBT activists hijacked the campaign, "urging people around the globe to use the cans to highlight messages about Russian anti-gay brutality."<ref>{{cite news |author=Michelangelo Signorile |url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/michelangelo-signorile/olympic-sponsors-were-war_b_4679919.html |title=Olympic Sponsors Were Warned About Sochi; Now McDonald's and Coca-Cola Are Having a PR Nightmare |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date=2014-01-28 |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> * (29 January 2014) Head of the Sochi Organizing Committee, [[Dmitry Chernyshenko]], expressed clarifications of athletes making political statements during their news conferences at the Games. Contradicting IOC president [[Thomas Bach]], who said athletes could make political statements during their media interviews, Chernyshenko said a [[free speech zone]] would be available for speaking about politics ten miles away from Olympic venues.<ref>[http://www.rferl.org/content/russia-olympics-contradicts-ioc/25247115.html Russian Olympics Chief Contradicts IOC Head On Political Statements], Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty.</ref><ref name="bbc.co.uk">{{cite news |last=Bond |first=David |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-25955930 |title=Sochi 2014: UK cash for Russian gay rights campaigners |publisher=BBC |date=2014-01-29 |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref><ref group=note>Three protest parks were designated in Beijing during the [[2008 Summer Olympics]], at the suggestion of the [[IOC]]. All 77 applications to protest there had been withdrawn or denied, and no protests took place. Four persons who applied to protest were arrested or sentenced to reeducation.([https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/08/20/AR2008082001095.html Elderly Chinese Women Sentenced to Labor Re-education], ''The Washington Post'', August 20, 2008; Peter Foster, [http://blogs.telegraph.co.uk/news/peterfoster/4959989/The_IOC_plays_appeaser_in_Beijing/ The IOC plays appeaser in Beijing], ''Telegraph Blogs'', August 20, 2008.)</ref> * (29 January 2014) In an interview with the BBC, British Culture Secretary Maria Miller said the UK government would provide extra funding for gay rights campaigners in Russia, in conjunction with the Olympic Games opportunity.<ref name="bbc.co.uk"/> * (29 January 2014) LGBT media-watchdog group [[GLAAD]] (Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation) launched a resource guide for journalists covering the 2014 Olympics, as well as Global Voices program, "sharing culture-changing stories of LGBT people and families in national and international media."<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.glaad.org/blog/glaad-unveils-olympic-playbook-launches-global-voices-program |title=GLAAD unveils Olympic Playbook, launches Global Voices program |publisher=Glaad.org |date=2014-01-29 |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> * (30 January 2014) The [[Principle 6 campaign]], "named after the clause in the Olympic charter that supposedly guarantees non-discrimination", was launched with over 50 current and former Olympians protesting Russia's anti-LGBT policies. The campaign criticized Games officials and sponsors for lack of action, and called on Russian authorities to reconsider the laws that led to "a wave of homophobic attacks."<ref>{{cite web |author=Owen Gibson | author2=Shaun Walker |url= https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2014/jan/30/olympic-athletes-russia-repeal-anti-gay-laws?CMP=twt_gu |title=Olympians urge Russia to reconsider 'gay propaganda' laws: Current and former Olympians criticise Games officials and sponsors for lack of action over anti-gay measures |publisher=Theguardian.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> * (31 January 2014) A new campaign called "Anything But Coke" was launched protesting Coca-Cola's "refusal to denounce these human rights abuses" regarding Russia's crackdown. Actions were slated for college and high school campuses in the U.S.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.towleroad.com/2014/01/anything-but-coke-college-campaign-pushes-for-lgbt-rights-in-russia-video.html |title= ‘Anything But Coke’ College Campaign Pushes For Lgbt Rights In Russia: Video |publisher=Towleroad.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> * (31 January 2014) In Stockholm, Sweden, 2000 people gathered to produce a video as part of a "Live and Let Love" campaign, showing support for Russian LGBT people.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.towleroad.com/2014/01/thousands-gather-in-stockholm-to-sing-in-support-of-the-lgbt-people-in-russia-video.html |title=Thousands Gather In Stockholm To Sing In Support Of The Lgbt People In Russia: Video |publisher=Towleroad.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> * (31 January 2014) An open letter to the ten world sponsors of the Olympics "urging them to denounce the law and run ads promoting equality for lesbians, gays, bisexuals and transgender people" was signed by 40 human rights and gay rights groups including [[Amnesty International]], [[Human Rights Watch]], and the [[Human Rights Campaign]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://stlouis.cbslocal.com/2014/01/31/sochi-olympics-surronded-with-turmoil/ |title=Sochi Olympics Surrounded By Turmoil |publisher=Stlouis.cbslocal.com |date=2014-01-31 |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> * (1 February 2014) Activists from various non-governmental groups protested in Paris by forming the five Olympic ring symbol with people and large images of violence against lesbian and gay people.<ref>{{cite web |agency=Associated Press |url= http://www.canada.com/olympics/news/lgbt-protests-focus-on-olympic-sponsors-coke-and-mcdonalds |title=LGBT protests focus on Olympic sponsors Coke and McDonald's |publisher=Canada.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> * (2 February 2014) Finnish Olympic swimmer [[Ari-Pekka Liukkonen]] came out publicly as gay to "raise awareness about Russia's anti-gay laws ahead of the Sochi Games."<ref>{{cite news |url= http://yle.fi/urheilu/suomalainen_olympiauimari_kaapista_ulos_-_vihdoin_voin_olla_oma_itseni/7065006 |title=Suomalainen olympiauimari kaapista ulos – "Vihdoin voin olla oma itseni" |date=2014-02-02 |publisher=[[Yle]] |language=Finnish |accessdate=2 February 2014}}</ref> Liukkonen was the first Finnish athlete to come out of the closet while still active in his sport. He competed at the 2012 London Olympics and has won bronze at the European Championships.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.towleroad.com/2014/02/finnish-olympian-swimmer-ari-pekka-liukkonen-comes-out-as-gay-to-raise-awareness-about-sochi.html |title=Finnish Olympian Swimmer Ari-Pekka Liukkonen Comes Out As Gay To Raise Awareness About Sochi |publisher=Towleroad.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> * (4 February 2014) A Russian ninth-grade girl from the [[Bryansk]] region was punished for violating the gay propaganda law after she openly announced her "nontraditional sexual orientation."<ref name=rferl/> It was the first case against a Russian minor under the controversial law, and the incident will appear on her criminal record.<ref name=rferl>{{cite web |url= http://www.rferl.org/content/russia-teen-gay-propaganda/25251319.html |title=Russian Teen Punished For 'Gay Propaganda' |publisher=Rferl.org |date=2014-02-03 |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> * (4 February 2014) The Canadian Institute of Diversity and Inclusion released a humorous, two-man [[luge]]-themed [[public service announcement]] in support of LGBT rights, with the tagline "The Games have always been a little gay. Let's fight to keep them that way." Michael Bach, head of the Institute, stated that it was intended to make "a really strong message about the need for equality and the treatment of LGBT people and their allies, particularly at the Olympics"<ref name=lat-lugepsa>{{cite news |title=Canadian PSA: 'The Olympics have always been a little gay' |url= http://articles.latimes.com/2014/feb/06/news/la-sh-canadian-luge-psa-20140206 |work=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=23 March 2014 |first=Stacey |last=Leasca |date=2014-02-06}}</ref> * (4 February 2014) [[AT&T]], a sponsor of the [[United States Olympic Committee]], became the first major U.S. corporation to publicly condemn Russia's LGBT propaganda law and show a pro-LGBT stance.<ref name=atthp/> The [[Human Rights Campaign]] had called on major corporations including the worldwide Olympic sponsors to condemn the laws.<ref name=atthp>{{cite news |author=James Nichols |url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/02/04/att-russia-anti-gay_n_4724374.html |title=AT&T Becomes First Major U.S. Corporation To Condemn Russia's Anti-Gay Laws |publisher=Huffington Post |date= 2014-02-04 |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> * (4 February 2014) Norway's openly gay health minister [[Bent Høie]] announced he would attend the [[2014 Winter Paralympics]] with his husband.<ref name=gnhm/> It is common for cabinet officials to travel with their spouses.<ref name=gnhm>{{cite news |url= http://ca.reuters.com/article/sportsNews/idCABREA130L420140204?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel=0 |title=Gay Norwegian minister to take husband to Sochi Paralympics |publisher=Ca.reuters.com |date=2014-02-04 |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> * (4 February 2014) [[Svetlana Zhurova]], a former Olympic champion and mayor of the Olympic Village for the Mountain cluster, called for no protests during the Games, stating that "We are all participants of the Games and we are going to applaud the straight people and the homosexuals just like the previous Olympic Games."<ref>{{cite web |author=Thomson Reuters Foundation |url=http://www.trust.org/item/20140204133334-d1vz3 |title=Olympics-Don't protest for gay rights in Sochi – Olympic village mayor |publisher=Trust.org |date=2014-02-04 |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> She had recently appeared on Russian television defending the ban on gay propaganda.<ref>{{cite web |author=Lucien Mae |url= http://dot429.com/articles/3846-russian-olympic-village-mayor-speaks-up-for-controversial-law |title=Russian Olympic Village "mayor" speaks up for controversial law |publisher=Dot429.com |date=2014-01-15 |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> * (4 February 2014) LGBT ally, National Football League's [[Chris Kluwe]], encouraged Sochi Olympians to speak up about "abuse against LGBTQ people in Russia", in London's ''[[The Guardian]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/feb/04/sochi-olympics-athletes-must-speak-up?CMP=twt_gu |title=Athletes in Sochi must speak up about Russia's intolerance. I did it in the NFL: Olympians shouldn't be silent about abuse against LGBTQ people in Russia. Doing what's right is better than winning |publisher=Theguardian.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> * (6 February 2014) The [[Russia Freedom Fund]], [[Athlete Ally]], and [[CoPilot]] partnered with the [[Fair Games Project]], producing a PSA protesting Russia treatment of LGBT people, and highlighting similar abuses in other countries.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.towleroad.com/2014/02/russiandiscrimination.html |title=Ugly 'Sport' Of Global Anti-Gay Oppression Highlighted In Powerful New Psa: Video Premiere |publisher=Towleroad.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> * (6 February 2014) Two USOC sponsors, the [[Chobani]] yogurt company and [[DeVry University]], publicly stated opposition to the LGBT propaganda law and support for efforts for LGBT equality.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.towleroad.com/2014/02/chobani-yogurt-ceo-we-oppose-russias-anti-lgbt-law.html |title=Chobani Yogurt Ceo: 'We Oppose Russia's Anti-Lgbt Law' |publisher=Towleroad.com |date=2014-02-06 |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> Chobani's CEO stated, "We oppose Russia's anti-LGBT law", in an interview on CNBC.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.towleroad.com/2014/02/chobani-shows-its-pride-photo.html |title=Chobani Shows Its Pride: Photo |publisher=Towleroad.com |date=2014-02-09 |accessdate=2014-02-17}}</ref>
===2014 (during the Games)=== * (4 February 2014) A number of major Canadian cities, including [[Calgary]], [[Edmonton]], [[Halifax, Nova Scotia|Halifax]], [[Quebec City]], [[St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador|St. John's]], and [[Toronto]], began to fly rainbow flags on government buildings in recognition of the rights of LGBT people in Russia.<ref name=nfrfd>{{cite web|url=http://www.towleroad.com/2014/02/newfoundland-and-labrador-communities-to-raise-gay-pride-flags-during-olympics.html |title=Newfoundland And Labrador Communities To Raise Gay Pride Flags During Olympics |publisher=Towleroad.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref><ref name=cbc-rainbowflagcdn>{{cite news|title=Rainbow flag raised at Calgary's City Hall in support of gay rights|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/calgary/rainbow-flag-raised-at-calgary-s-city-hall-in-support-of-gay-rights-1.2527823|work=CBC News|accessdate=23 March 2014|date=2014-02-07}}</ref> By the end of the games, the campaign has been joined by at least 33 cities and the provincial legislatures of eight of Canada's ten provinces. * (6 February 2014) [[Google]] changed its [[List of Google Doodles in 2014|front page logo]] to a rainbow-coloured [[Google Doodle]] with pictograms of sports linking to a search for "[[Olympic Charter]]", and placed a quote from the charter on the page as well.<ref name=csmgd>{{cite web|author=Pat Murphy |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Sports/2014/0206/Google-doodle-points-to-Olympic-Charter-in-defending-all-athletes-video |title=Google doodle points to Olympic Charter in defending all athletes |work=Christian Science Monitor |date= |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> The doodle was characterized in media as a symbolic protest, although Google specifically refused to acknowledge it.<ref>{{cite web|author=Mark Molloy |url=http://metro.co.uk/2014/02/07/google-doodle-goes-rainbow-for-gay-rights-ahead-of-sochi-winter-olympics-2014-4294426/ |title=Sochi Winter Olympics 2014: Rainbow Google Doodle supports gay rights in Russia | Metro News |publisher=Metro.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2014-02-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/feb/07/google-russian-anti-gay-laws-winter-olympics |title=Rainbow Google doodle links to Olympic charter as Sochi kicks off: Search engine's logo presented in the colours of the rainbow flag to coincide with the opening of the Winter Olympics in Sochi |publisher=Theguardian.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> * (7 February 2014) Just ahead of the [[2014 Winter Olympics opening ceremony|opening ceremony]], four LGBT activists, including Anastasia Smirnova, Aleksandra Semenova and a pregnant woman, were arrested in [[St. Petersburg]] for holding up a banner reading "Discrimination is incompatible with the Olympic movement. Principle 6. Olympic charter."<ref>{{cite news |author=Curtis M. Wong |url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/02/07/russia-gay-propaganda-arrests_n_4745481.html |title=Russian LGBT Activists Arrested Under 'Gay Propaganda' Law In St. Petersburg |publisher=Huffington Post |date= 2014-02-07 |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> * (7 February 2014) U.S. President Barack Obama confirmed in an interview with [[NBC Sports]]' [[Bob Costas]] that the inclusion of gay athletes in the U.S. Olympic delegation was to send a pointed message in response to the Russian laws, saying that "there is no doubt we wanted to make it very clear that we do not abide by discrimination in anything, including discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation. One of the wonderful things about the Olympics is that you are judged by your merit, how good you are regardless of where you come from, what you look like, who you love and that I think is consistent with the spirit of the Olympics."<ref name=thr-obamanbc>{{cite news |title=Olympics: Obama, Bob Costas Chat About 'Tough Guy' Putin During Interview (Video) |url= http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/olympics-obama-bob-costas-chat-678042 |work=The Hollywood Reporter |accessdate=10 February 2014 |first=Philiana |last=Ng}}</ref> * (7 February 2014) The ''[[Huffington Post]]'' noted that the opening ceremony, ironically given Russia's LGBT stance and the associated protest movement, featured tributes to "some of history's most widely acclaimed and definitely gay Russians", including composer [[Peter Tchaikovsky]] (1840–1893); Ukrainian-born Russian humorist, dramatist, and novelist [[Nikolai Gogol]] (1809–1852); filmmaker [[Sergei Eisenstein]] (1898–1948); ballet dancer [[Vaslav Nijinsky]] (1889–1950); and patron of arts and founder of [[Ballets Russes]], [[Sergei Diaghilev]].<ref name=huffpost-russiagayceremony>{{cite news |title=Nobody Tell Russia, But Look How Super Gay Their Olympics Opening Ceremony Was |url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/02/07/olympics-opening-ceremony-gay_n_4746760.html |work=Huffington Post |publisher=AOL |accessdate=25 February 2014 |date=2014-02-07}}</ref><ref name=advocate-22russians>{{cite web |title=22 Russians Who We Won't Let Vladimir Putin Forget Were LGBT |url= http://www.advocate.com/arts-entertainment/people/2013/08/06/22-russians-who-we-wont-let-vladimir-putin-forget-were-gay?page=full |work=The Advocate |accessdate=25 February 2014}}</ref> On the same topic, critics also noted that the Russian pop duo [[t.A.T.u]] were invited to perform during the opening ceremony. Although they are not actually lesbian, the all-female duo were well known for incorporating themes of lesbianism in their music and on-stage personas (live appearances often featured the singers kissing each other), their name is a corruption of a shortened Russian phrase meaning "this girl loves that girl", and the duo made a statement in support of LGBT rights in the wake of [[Yuri Luzhkov]]'s objection to the 2007 [[Moscow Pride]] [[gay pride parade|parade]].<ref name=pinknews-tatumoscowpride>{{cite web |title=Russian pop duo tATu support Moscow Pride |url= http://www.pinknews.co.uk/2007/05/17/russian-pop-duo-tatu-support-moscow-pride/ |work=Pink News |accessdate=25 February 2014}}</ref> Organizers noted that t.A.T.u were chosen because they were well known to an international audience.<ref name=thr-tatu>{{cite news |title=Sochi: Fake Lesbian Russian Pop Duo t.A.T.u. to Perform at Olympics' Opening Ceremony |url= http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/sochi-tatu-perform-at-olympics-677751 |work=The Hollywood Reporter |accessdate=13 February 2014}}</ref> * (7 February 2014) During the opening ceremony IOC president [[Thomas Bach]] made a speech which made strong statements against discrimination:<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.towleroad.com/2014/02/nbc-edited-out-ioc-anti-discrimination-remarks-from-opening-ceremony-broadcast.html |title=NBC Edited Out IOC Anti-Discrimination Remarks From Opening Ceremony Broadcast |publisher=Towleroad.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-17}}</ref> {{quote|Yes, Yes, it is possible – even as competitors – to live together under one roof in harmony, with tolerance and without any form of discrimination for whatever reason.<ref>{{cite web |author= |url= http://deadspin.com/nbc-edits-out-ioc-anti-discrimination-statement-from-op-1518727938 |title=NBC Edits Out IOC Anti-Discrimination Statement From Opening Ceremony |publisher=Deadspin.com |date=2014-02-07 |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref>}} * (7 February 2014) [[Cheryl Maas]], one of six reportedly outed competitors in the Games, made the first display of LGBT "propaganda" in solidarity with Russian LGBT persons. Following her attempt to qualify in the slopestyle event at Sochi, Cheryl Maas, from the Netherlands, who is openly married to another woman, raised her glove bearing a rainbow (and a unicorn) to the cameras. The snowboarder has reportedly previously criticized the decision to hold the Games in Sochi, stating, "With the choice of Russia, the IOC is taking a step back in time." <ref>{{cite news|author=James Nichols |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/02/07/olympics-rainbow-glove_n_4745548.html |title=Cheryl Maas, Lesbian Snowboarder In Russia, Raises Rainbow Glove In Sochi |publisher=Huffington Post|date= 2014-02-07|accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> * (10 February 2014) On ESPN's ''Outside the Lines'', 24-year-old [[Callan Chythlook-Sifsof]], an Olympic snowboarder,<ref name=sbdh>{{cite web|url=http://www.towleroad.com/2014/02/us-snowboarder-callan-chythlook-sifsof-im-gay.html |title=U.S. Snowboarder Callan Chythlook-Sifsof: I'M Gay |publisher=Towleroad.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-17}}</ref> said she wanted to [[coming out|come out]] at Sochi to make a statement about LGBT rights in light of Russia's law, but she missed the cut for Team USA.<ref name=sbdh/> * (13 February 2014) A group of friends from Amsterdam, The Netherlands, released "Putin Gay Dress Up",<ref>http://www.putingaydressup.com {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20141018190705/http://www.putingaydressup.com/ |date=2014-10-18 }}</ref> an online game to protest against Putin's statements about gay rights. Players had to dress up the president as a stereotyped gay, including woman's clothes and a Pussy Riot T-shirt.<ref>http://www.indiegamemag.com/putin-gay-dress-up-makes-a-political-statement/</ref>
==See also== * [[Concerns and controversies at the 2014 Winter Olympics]] * [[James Kirchick]] * [[List of LGBT sportspeople]] * [[Human rights in Russia]] * [[LGBT rights in Russia]] * [[LGBT rights in Asia]] * [[LGBT rights in Europe]] * [[LGBT history in Russia]] * [[Mayer Brown]] * [[Uprising of Love]]

page.title: Lighthouse and naval vessel urban legend

revision.comment: standard quote handling in WP;standard Apostrophe/quotation marks in WP; MOS general fixes
revision.text:
{{short description|"I'm a lighthouse. Your call"}} {{Use mdy dates |date = September 2011}} {{multiple image |align = right |direction = horizontal |width = |image1 = USS Enterprise (CVN-65).jpg |width1 = 200 |alt1 = A large gray ship with a flat surface and tower in the middle traveling through the sea |caption1 = The ''[[USS Enterprise (CVN-65)|USS Enterprise]]'', a large warship of the U.S. Navy |image2 = Ferryland Lighthouse.jpg |width2 = 93 |alt2 = A tall red round building with a glassed-in top and a walkway around it. The ocean is visible in the distance. |caption2 = A Canadian lighthouse }} The '''lighthouse and naval vessel urban legend''' describes an encounter between a large naval ship and what at first appears to be another vessel, with which the ship is on a [[collision course]]. The naval vessel, usually identified as of the [[United States Navy]] and generally described as a [[battleship]] or [[aircraft carrier]], requests that the other ship change course. The other party (generally identified as [[Canadians|Canadian]] or often [[Ireland|Irish]] and occasionally [[Spain|Spanish]]) responds that the naval vessel should change course, whereupon the captain of the naval vessel reiterates the demand, identifying himself and the ship he commands and sometimes making threats. This elicits a response worded as "'''I'm a [[lighthouse]]. Your call'''" (or similarly), a punchline which has become shorthand for the entire anecdote.
It has circulated on the Internet and elsewhere in particular since a 1995 iteration that was represented as an actual transcript of such a communication released by the office of the U.S. [[Chief of Naval Operations]]. There appears to be no evidence that the event actually took place, and the account is implausible for several reasons.<ref name="Fast Company article">{{cite news |last = Chadderdon |first = Lisa |title = This Time, Consultants Are In The Dark |url = http://www.fastcompany.com/magazine/27/cdu.html |newspaper = [[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]] |date = August 31, 1999 |accessdate = September 17, 2011 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110528151136/http://www.fastcompany.com/magazine/27/cdu.html |archivedate = May 28, 2011 |df = mdy-all }}</ref> It is thus considered an [[urban legend]], a variation on a joke that dates to at least the 1930s,<ref name="Snopes page">{{cite web |last = Mikkelson |first = Barbara |authorlink = Barbara Mikkelson |title = The Obstinate Lighthouse |url = http://www.snopes.com/military/lighthouse.asp |publisher = [[Snopes.com]] |date = March 18, 2008 |accessdate = September 17, 2011}}</ref> sometimes referred to as "'''the lighthouse vs. the carrier'''" or "'''the lighthouse vs. the battleship'''". The U.S. Navy has a webpage debunking it,<ref name="USN denial">{{cite web |title = The Lighthouse Joke |publisher = [[United States Navy]] |url = http://www.navy.mil/navydata/questions/litehuse.html |date = September 2, 2009 |accessdate = September 17, 2011}}</ref> although this did not stop the former U.S. [[United States Director of National Intelligence|Director of National Intelligence]] [[John Michael McConnell|Mike McConnell]] using it as a joke in a 2008 speech.<ref name="McConnell speech">{{cite news |last = Silva |first = Mark |title = DNI Mike McConnell: 'America hates spies' |url = http://www.swamppolitics.com/news/politics/blog/2008/03/dni_mike_mcconnell_america_hat.html|newspaper=Chicago Tribune |date = March 13, 2008 |accessdate = September 17, 2011}}</ref> Other speakers have often used it simply as a [[parable]] teaching the dangers of inflexibility and [[egotism|self-importance]], or the need for [[situation awareness]]. In 2004 a Swedish company dramatized it in an award-winning television advertisement.<ref name="Silva ad blog post">{{cite web |first = Duncan |last = Macleod |title = Silva Captain and the Lighthouse |url = http://theinspirationroom.com/daily/2006/silva-the-captain-and-the-lighthouse/ |publisher = The Inspiration Room |date = December 3, 2006 |accessdate = September 17, 2011}}</ref>
== Example == A commonly circulated version goes thus:<ref name="Snopes page" />
{{quote box|This is the transcript of a radio conversation of a US naval ship with Canadian authorities off the coast of [[Newfoundland (island)|Newfoundland]] in October, 1995. Radio conversation released by the [[Chief of Naval Operations]] 10-10-95.
::Americans: Please divert your course 15 degrees to the North to avoid a collision.
::Canadians: Recommend you divert YOUR course 15 degrees to the South to avoid a collision.
::Americans: This is the Captain of a US Navy ship. I say again, divert YOUR course.
::Canadians: No. I say again, you divert YOUR course.
::Americans: This is the aircraft carrier ''[[USS Abraham Lincoln (CVN-72)|USS Lincoln]]'', the second largest ship in the United States' [[United States Fleet Forces Command|Atlantic fleet]]. We are accompanied by three destroyers, three cruisers and numerous support vessels. I demand that YOU change your course 15 degrees north, that's one five degrees north, or countermeasures will be undertaken to ensure the safety of this ship.
::Canadians: This is a [[List of lighthouses in Newfoundland and Labrador|lighthouse]]. Your call.<ref name="Snopes page" />}}
Other vessels sometimes named in the transcript include the carriers ''[[USS Enterprise (CVN-65)|Enterprise]]'', ''[[USS Coral Sea (CV-43)|Coral Sea]]'' and ''[[USS Nimitz (CVN-68)|Nimitz]]'', and the ''[[USS Missouri (BB-63)|Missouri]]'', a battleship.<ref name="Snopes page" /><ref name="USN denial" /> The location of the exchange has also sometimes been claimed to be [[Puget Sound]], or off the coast of [[North Carolina]], some other times the lighthouse is located at [[Cape Finisterre]] ([[Spain]]).<ref>Youtube: [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6filPCtrt0c Hilarious Radio Conversation between US Naval Ship and Spanish Authorities]</ref> (The Spanish version expands the joke by having the lighthouse keeper respond to the aircraft carrier's inventory of the fleet by saying he's accompanied by "our dog, our food, two beers, and a canary that's currently asleep.") Some versions relocate it to the Irish or Scottish<ref name="Scottish version">{{cite web |title = Scottish Humour, Real Life Stories |url = http://www.rampantscotland.com/humour/blhumreal.htm |publisher = RampantScotland.com |accessdate = September 20, 2011}}</ref> coasts; in the former case the ship is sometimes identified as British, with the conversation taking place off the coast of [[County Kerry|Kerry]] in 1998.<ref name="The Levity Effect">{{cite book |first1 = Adrian |last1 = Gostick |first2 = Scott |last2 = Christopher |title = The Levity Effect: Why It Pays to Lighten Up |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=M-IcnWTal0cC|date = 2010-12-29 |publisher = John Wiley & Sons |location = New York, NY |isbn = 978-1-118-03941-0 |pages = 107–08 }}</ref> There is sometimes an additional line of dialogue where the [[lighthouse keeper]] tells the ship captain he is a [[Seaman First Class]] before the final exchange.<ref>{{cite book |last = Greenfield |first = Gary |title = Life's Ride Or Fall ... You Make the Call: Thoughts, Stories, Lessons Learned and Actionable Ideas to Help Create the Ride of Your Life! |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=bY4f7WIGviYC |date = 2008-05-07 |publisher = AuthorHouse |isbn = 978-1-4343-6184-4 |page = 118 }}</ref> The prefatory information sometimes notes it was released in response to a request under the [[Freedom of Information Act (United States)|Freedom of Information Act]], and/or names [[Jeremy Boorda]], the incumbent Chief of Naval Operations on the stated date.
== Debunking == ''[[The Virginian-Pilot]]'', the daily newspaper in [[Norfolk, Virginia]], a city with a large naval presence, investigated the story after it had begun circulating extensively on and off the Internet in 1995. A spokesman for the Atlantic Fleet called it "a totally bogus story". Boorda's office said it had not released any such transcript on the date in question. And not only was the story an old one, the ships commonly named in it were mostly either out of service by 1995 (the ''Coral Sea'', in fact, had been scrapped two years before)<ref name="Fast Company article" /> or not aircraft carriers.<ref name="V-P article cited at Snopes">{{cite news |last = Addis |first = David |title = Standoff: Navy Says No Lighthouse – No Comment|newspaper=[[The Virginian-Pilot]] |date = March 14, 1996}} Cited by Mikkelson.</ref>
Other sources the paper consulted found more flaws with the story. A spokesman for the [[United States Coast Guard|Coast Guard]], which operates all American lighthouses, said that they had all long since been automated, so there would have been no one in one to talk to a ship, if the incident had taken place in U.S. waters. He speculated that it had been circulated by members of the Coast Guard to make fun of the Navy.<ref name="V-P article cited at Snopes" />
Four years later, in response to a report that a consultant continued to tell the story at speeches as if it were a true occurrence, ''[[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]]'' talked to Wayne Wheeler, a former Coast Guardsman who was then head of an enthusiasts' group called the U.S. Lighthouse Society. He confirmed that it was an old story, and that in his experience with lighthouses was highly unlikely:
{{quote|text = First, a lighthouse doesn't look anything like a ship. Unless the weather's really foggy—and most versions of the story don't mention fog — you can see a lighthouse from far away as [[light characteristic|a fixed white light that flashes at a set number of seconds]]. On the other hand, ships are usually moving and have smaller, colored lights at the fore and aft. There's absolutely no way to mistake one for the other.}} An actual Canadian lighthouse keeper, Jim Abram of British Columbia, agreed. "I've been lighthouse keeping for 21 years," he told the magazine, "and no one's ever thought that I was in anything but a lighthouse."<ref name="Fast Company article" />
The [[Military Officers Association of America]] (MOAA) calls it "easily believable if you are not familiar with how the Navy operates or simple things such as [[Global Positioning System|GPS]]." In addition to the historical inaccuracies with most of the ships named, the organization notes on its blog the extreme improbability that an aircraft carrier's crew would not realize they were off the coast of a landmass such as Newfoundland. The MOAA claims to receive it in [[email forwarding|forwarded email]] an average of three times a day. "[After] fifty times the only interesting part about it is to see which details have been changed."<ref name="MOAA blog entry">{{cite web |last = LoFiego |first = Mathew |title = Classic Bilge: The Lighthouse vs. The Aircraft Carrier |url = http://www.moaablogs.org/battleofthebilge/2009/03/classic-bilge-the-lighthouse-vs-the-aircraft-carrier/ |publisher = [[Military Officers Association of America]] |date = March 29, 2009 |accessdate = September 20, 2011}}</ref>
== History == The earliest known version of the joke appeared in a single-panel cartoon, reproduced from the London tabloid weekly ''The Humorist'' by the Canadian newspaper ''The Drumheller Review'' in 1931. It showed two men standing by their rails, shouting through megaphones:
"Skipper: Where are you going with your blinking ship? / The Other: "This isn't a blinking ship. It's a lighthouse!""
In August of 1934, the London weekly ''Answers'', founded by [[Alfred Harmsworth, 1st Viscount Northcliffe|Alfred Harmsworth]], expanded the cartoon into a humorous anecdote, which was reprinted on both sides of the Atlantic. This version read:
{{quote box|align=center|There was a dense summer fog and the officer on the bridge was becoming more and more exasperated. As he leaned over the side of the bridge trying to pierce the gloom, he saw a hazy figure leaning on a rail a few yards from his ship.
He almost choked.
"What do you think you're doing with your blinking ship?" he roared. "Don't you know the rules of the sea?
"This ain't no blinkin' ship, guv'nor," said a quiet voice; "this 'ere's a light'ouse!"<ref name="Snopes page" />}}
Variants appeared in humor books and periodicals over the next several decades. In 1943, [[Raphael Tuck & Sons]] issued a postcard version, with an illustration of the prow of an ocean liner and passing a uniformed man at the rail of a similar object: "Where the ell are you going on your perishin' ship? / This ain't no ship, it's a lighthouse!"
[[Steven Covey]] told his own version in his 1989 bestseller ''[[The Seven Habits of Highly Effective People]]'',<ref name="Covey at Snopes">{{cite book |last = Covey |first = Stephen R. |authorlink = Stephen Covey |title = The Seven Habits of Highly Effective People |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=n060QgAACAAJ |year = 1989 |publisher = Simon & Schuster |isbn = 978-0-671-71117-7 |pages = 32–33 }} Cited by Mikkelson</ref> and Covey in turn cited an issue of ''[[Proceedings (magazine)|Proceedings]]'' published two years earlier.<ref name="Proceedings at Snopes">{{cite journal |last = Koch |first = Frank |title = Pulling Rank|journal=[[Proceedings (magazine)|Proceedings]] |date = November 1987|page=81}} Cited by Mikkelson.</ref> [[Isaac Asimov]] included it in a 1992 humor anthology.<ref name="Asimov at Snopes">{{cite book |last = Asimov |first = Isaac |title = Asimov Laughs Again |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=HvtkAAAAMAAJ |date = 1992-03-11 |publisher = HarperCollins |isbn = 978-0-06-016826-1 |page = 119 }} Cited by Mikkelson.</ref>
Since 1995, the story continues to be told, albeit with some awareness that it is probably fictional.<ref name="Glow in the Dark">{{cite book |authorlink1 = Bill Bright |first1 = Bill |last1 = Bright |first2 = Ron |last2 = Jenson |title = Glow in the Dark: A Life that Lights The Way |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=h2BB22jtM9IC |date = 2005-08-01 |publisher = Random House Digital |isbn = 978-1-59052-485-5 |pages = 29–30 |quote = Apocryphal or not ...}}</ref><ref name="Borderlands">{{cite book |last = New |first = W.H. |title = Borderlands: How We Talk About Canada |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=v5nlp2Z2b7IC |date = 1998-06-01 |publisher = UBC Press |isbn = 978-0-7748-0659-6 |page = 68 |quote = I do not know its origin and I suspect it to be apocryphal ...}}</ref> In 2004 [[Silva compass]], a Swedish maker of marine navigational equipment, dramatized it in a television ad called "The Captain". Its version was set in the [[Irish Sea]], with the ship called the [[USS Montana|USS ''Montana'']]{{efn|No actual U.S. Navy ship has used that name since the early 20th century.}} and an Irish lighthouse keeper.<ref name="Silva ad blog post" /> The advertisement, filmed in English with [[Swedish language|Swedish]] subtitles, won a Bronze Lion at that year's [[Cannes Lions International Advertising Festival]].<ref name="Cannes 2004 awards">{{cite web |url= http://www.canneslions.com/downloads/winners_pdfs/Cannes_Lions_2004_Film_Lions_Winners.pdf |title= Cannes Lions 2004 Film Award Winners |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110627051759/http://www.canneslions.com/downloads/winners_pdfs/Cannes_Lions_2004_Film_Lions_Winners.pdf |archivedate= June 27, 2011 |df= mdy-all }}, retrieved September 20, 2011; p. 4.</ref>
Four years later, in 2008, retired Admiral [[John Michael McConnell|Mike McConnell]], then [[United States Director of National Intelligence|Director of National Intelligence]], used the anecdote at the beginning of a speech at [[Johns Hopkins University]]. He insisted it was a true story. "I was in the signals intelligence business where you listen to the people talk and so on" he told his listeners beforehand. "This is true. It's an actual recording."<ref name="Snopes page" /> When he was later questioned on this, a spokesman said those statements were meant merely to set the audience up. "It's a technique—comedians use it all the time to get the audience to buy in".<ref name="Gail Collins column">{{cite news |last = Collins |first = Gail |authorlink = Gail Collins |title = A Black Hole Rating System |url = https://www.nytimes.com/2008/04/03/opinion/03collins.html |newspaper = [[The New York Times]] |date = April 3, 2008 |accessdate = September 20, 2011}}</ref>
== Interpretations == Most commentators who have used it in speeches or books point to it as Mikkelson does, "a lesson in the unimportance of [[egotism|self-importance]]".<ref name="Snopes page" /> [[Felix Dennis]], in whose retelling the story, represented as true, takes place off the coast of British Columbia, calls it his "favorite story about the 'infallibility' of power". He comments: {{quote|Oh, boy. Naturally that officer of the watch can never have lived it down. He will be nicknamed "Your Call" or "Lighthouse" until the day he retires. All those years of saluting and keeping his nose to the grindstone destroyed in moments, because he believed the sun shone out of his backside.<ref name="Felix Dennis book">{{cite book |last = Dennis |first = Felix |authorlink = Felix Dennis |title = How to Get Rich: One of the World's Greatest Entrepreneurs Shares His Secrets |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=meKL68N5esEC |date = 2008-06-17 |publisher = Penguin |location = London, England |isbn = 978-1-59184-205-7 |page = 282 }}</ref>}}
Others, particularly those writing about management for business audiences, see it as demonstrating the need for flexibility. Barry Maher calls the intractability of some listeners the ''Abraham Lincoln'' Syndrome after the ship named in his version of the anecdote, which he also represents as true. "When the person you're dealing with refuses to let you go where you want to go, divert your course", he advises salespeople, echoing the language in the story. "Smashing into lighthouses is not a successful navigational strategy—no matter how pushy those lighthouses might be."<ref name="Filling the Glass">{{cite book |last = Maher |first = Barry |title = Filling the Glass: The Skeptic's Guide to Positive Thinking in Business |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=FOTkCSHkkekC |date = January 2001 |publisher = Dearborn Trade Publishing |isbn = 978-0-7931-3865-4 |pages = 142–43 }}</ref> Within a marital context, [[Gary Smalley]] uses it to advise husbands trying to reconcile with their wives that "like the navy captain's attempts to manipulate the lighthouse, your attempts to control the situation could cause your wife to become an immovable rock and resent you more deeply".<ref name="Winning Your Wife Back">{{cite book |first1 = Gary |last1 = Smalley |authorlink1 = Gary Smalley |first2 = Deborah |last2 = Smalley |first3 = Greg |last3 = Smalley |title = Winning Your Wife Back Before It's Too Late |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=w5v5trH7zCgC |date = 2004-09-16 |publisher = Thomas Nelson Inc |isbn = 978-0-7852-6028-8 |pages = 26–27 }}</ref>
Another [[wikt:exegesis|exegesis]] of the story is the importance of [[situational awareness]]. Christian media consultant [[Phil Cooke]] tells the story, conceding that it's fictional, and uses it to demonstrate the importance of the research he reads, and knowing one's audience in particular. "We're blind unless we know who we're talking to."<ref name="Phil Cooke page">{{cite web |last = Cooke |first = Phil |authorlink = Phil Cooke |title = Why Researching Your Audience Matters |url = http://philcooke.com/research_matters/ |publisher = PhilCooke.com |date = July 4, 2010 |accessdate = September 20, 2011}}</ref> "[W]hile it is [the captain']s ship, it's most definitely not his ocean" writes Russ Linden, a columnist at ''[[Governing (magazine)|Governing]]'', of the lesson offered.<ref>{{cite journal |last = Linden |first = Russ |title = How's Your 'Court Vision'? |journal = [[Governing (magazine)|Governing]] |date = August 10, 2011}}</ref>
Some speakers think the anecdote is an overused [[cliché]]. Alan Stevens, president of the Global Speakers Federation, noted that Covey was still using it in speeches in 2010, and reported that the same week he heard him use it a client emailed him that two speakers at a political event she attended had used it. He tells those giving speeches to avoid not only the lighthouse story, but the [[boiling frog]] story and the story about a young boy [[The Star Thrower|throwing beached starfish]] back into the sea. "They may have happened once, but they won't have happened to the storyteller. What's worse, they are used so often, they have lost their impact." They should instead follow his example and tell stories of things that actually happened to them or that they did themselves.<ref name="Alan Stevens">{{cite web |last = Stevens |first = Alan |title = Beware starfish, boiling frogs and lighthouses |url = http://www.ecademy.com/node.php?id=157403 |publisher = Ecademy.com |date = November 28, 2010 |accessdate = September 20, 2011}}</ref>
== See also == {{Portal|United States Navy|Battleships|Nautical|Canada}} * [[Elbow of Cross Ledge Light]], a New Jersey lighthouse that was hit by a ship in 1953 * [[Moreton Bay Pile Light]], an Australian lighthouse twice hit by ships * [[List of Internet phenomena]]
== Notes == {{Notelist}}
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
== External links== * [http://www.snopes.com/military/lighthouse.asp The Obstinate Lighthouse] at [[Snopes.com]] * [http://www.navy.mil/navydata/questions/litehuse.html The Lighthouse Joke] at navy.mil

revision.text:
{{About|the locations of the 2017 Women's Marches|information about the 2017 Women's March movement as a whole|2017 Women's March}} {{Use mdy dates|date=January 2017}} The [[2017 Women's March]] was a series of [[political rally|political rallies]] that took place in cities around the world on January 21, 2017, with the goals of: protesting against Donald J. Trump's positions and Presidency; promoting [[women's rights]], immigration reform, climate science, and health care reform; countering [[religious discrimination]], [[violence against women]], and [[LGBTQ]] abuse; and addressing racial inequities (e.g. [[Black Lives Matter]]), workers' issues, and environmental issues.{{cite news |last1=Cauterucci |first1=Christina |title=The Women's March on Washington Has Released an Unapologetically Progressive Platform |url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/xx_factor/2017/01/12/the_women_s_march_on_washington_has_released_its_platform_and_it_is_unapologetically.html |accessdate=January 12, 2017 |work=Slate |date=January 12, 2017}} __TOC__{{-}} ==United States== Listed below are 680 marches in the U.S. in support of the 2017 Women's March.
{{hlist|[[#AK|AK]]|[[#AL|AL]]|[[#AR|AR]]|[[#AZ|AZ]]|[[#CA|CA]]|[[#CO|CO]]|[[#CT|CT]]|[[#DC|DC]]|[[#DE|DE]]|[[#FL|FL]]|[[#GA|GA]]|[[#GU|GU]]|[[#HI|HI]]|[[#ID|ID]]|[[#IL|IL]]|[[#IN|IN]]|[[#IA|IA]]|[[#KS|KS]]|[[#KY|KY]]|[[#LA|LA]]|[[#MA|MA]]|[[#MD|MD]]|[[#ME|ME]]|[[#MI|MI]]|[[#MN|MN]]|[[#MO|MO]]|[[#MS|MS]]|[[#MT|MT]]|[[#NC|NC]]|[[#ND|ND]]|[[#NE|NE]]|[[#NH|NH]]|[[#NJ|NJ]]|[[#NM|NM]]|[[#NV|NV]]|[[#NY|NY]]|[[#OH|OH]]|[[#OK|OK]]|[[#OR|OR]]|[[#PA|PA]]|[[#PR|PR]]|[[#RI|RI]]|[[#SC|SC]]|[[#SD|SD]]|[[#TN|TN]]|[[#TX|TX]]|[[#UT|UT]]|[[#VA|VA]]|[[#VI|VI]]|[[#VT|VT]]|[[#WA|WA]]|[[#WI|WI]]|[[#WV|WV]]|[[#WY|WY]]}}
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! scope="col" | State ! scope="col" | Cities ! scope="col" class="unsortable"| Photo ! scope="col" data-sort-type="number" |Approximate attendance ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Notes |- | colspan="2"|
{{flag|Washington, D.C.}}{{anchor|DC}}
|[[File:Womens March on Washington.jpg|center|125px]] |1,000,000{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/monkey-cage/wp/2017/02/07/this-is-what-we-learned-by-counting-the-womens-marches/|title=Analysis {{!}} This is what we learned by counting the women’s marches|last=Chenoweth|first=Erica|date=2017-02-07|work=Washington Post|access-date=2018-03-26|last2=Pressman|first2=Jeremy|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}} |[[Governor of Virginia|Virginia Governor]] [[Terry McAuliffe]] announced that he would attend the march instead of the inaugural parade. McAuliffe said he would be marching in Washington with his wife Dorothy, [[Ralph Northam|Lt. Gov. Ralph Northam]] and [[Cecile Richards]], president of the [[Planned Parenthood Federation of America]].{{Cite news |last1=Nolte |first1=Jessica |last2=Schiffres |first2=Megan |last3=Service |first3=Capital News |title=Gov. McAuliffe to join March on Washington |url=http://wric.com/2017/01/19/gov-mcauliffe-to-join-march-on-washington |publisher=WRIC |accessdate=January 25, 2017 |date=January 20, 2017}} There were no arrests.{{cite news |title=Not a Single Arrest in Massive D.C. The parade made its way from the parking lot at Springfield's municipal court building, across the Martin Luther King Jr. Bridge and over to Park Central Square where several speakers addressed the crowd. The rally touched on political issues in addition to women's rights. One speaker, Bethany Johnson, a transgender woman, spoke and drew some of the loudest cheers. She also mentioned the 2015 vote that repealed the city's ordinance banning LGBT discrimination in the workplace. Johnson banged the podium and called on the marchers to contact their politicians.Bologna, Giacomo (January 21, 2017). Marchers did not carry signs because nearly all poster materials at the station are U.S. Government property. |- ||[[Paradise Bay]] | |30{{Cite news |url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/1/21/14345528/womens-march-movement-antarctica |title=The Women's March movement is taking place on every continent, even Antarctica |last=Liptak |first=Andrew |date=January 21, 2017 |accessdate=January 21, 2017 |work=[[The Verge]]}} |People travelled to Paradise Bay for a "pro-peace, pro-environment" march, highlighting the environmental issues that affect the Antarctica climate they feel is threatened by Trump's stated policies.{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/01/21/politics/trump-women-march-on-washington/ |title=Protesters rally worldwide in solidarity with Washington march |date=January 21, 2017 |first=Laura |last=Smith-Spark |publisher=CNN |accessdate=January 18, 2017}} |- |{{flag|Argentina}}{{anchor|Argentina}} |[[Buenos Aires]] |[[File:Women's March in Buenos Aires 10.jpg|center|125px]] |100 |People gathered in front of the US embassy in Argentina. The protest was spontaneously organized by an American woman living in Buenos Aires, and joined by many American and Argentinean women and men. Other local political movements also joined, like Las Piqueteras.{{cite news |last1=McCay |first1=Katie |title=Standing with Washington: Women Protested Outside the US Embassy in Buenos Aires |url=http://www.thebubble.com/standing-with-washington-women-protested-outside-the-us-embassy-in-buenos-aires/ |accessdate=January 23, 2017 |agency=The Bubble |publisher=The Bubble, Inc. |date=January 23, 2017}} |- | rowspan="3" |{{flag|Australia}}{{anchor|Australia}} |Sydney |[[File:Women's March on Sydney passing through Pitt Street Mall.jpg|center|125px]] |8,000–10,000{{Cite news |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-usa-trump-women-asia-idUKKBN155037?il=0 |title=Thousands protest Trump as sister marches begin in Australia and New Zealand |last=Pearl |first=Harry |date=January 21, 2017 |agency=Reuters UK |accessdate=January 21, 2017}} |Protesters gathered in [[Hyde Park, Sydney|Hyde Park]]. Some Australian Trump supporters paid a [[skywriting]] company $4,000 to write "TRUMP" in the sky during the march.{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2017/jan/21/out-of-the-blue-trump-skywriting-appears-above-sydney-protest |title=Out of the blue: 'Trump' skywriting appears above Sydney protest |last2=Israel |first2=Janine |date=January 20, 2017 |last1=Slezak |first1=Michael |work=The Guardian |accessdate=January 21, 2017}} |- |[[Canberra]] | |1,000 |Participants gathered in [[Garema Place]].{{Cite news |url=http://www.scmp.com/news/world/united-states-canada/article/2064328/millions-join-us-womens-marches-vowing-resist |title=Millions join women's marches worldwide vowing to resist US President Trump |date=January 22, 2017 |work=[[South China Morning Post]] |accessdate=January 23, 2017}} |- |[[Melbourne]] | |5,000{{Cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/lifestyle/news-and-views/news-features/up-to-10000-join-sydney-womens-march-as-global-movement-protests-trump-inauguration-20170121-gtvz2i.html |title=Up to 10,000 join Sydney Women's March as global movement protests Trump inauguration |last2=De Bono |first2=Arielle |date=January 21, 2017 |last1=Noyes |first1=Jenny |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |accessdate=January 21, 2017}} to 7,000{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2017/01/21/millions-turn-out-worldwide-solidarity-washington-womens-march/96880344/ |title=Sydney, Tokyo, Dublin, Capetown: Women's March on Washington goes worldwide |last=Stanglin |first=Doug |date=January 21, 2017 |newspaper=[[USA Today]] |accessdate=January 22, 2017}} |People marched in from the [[State Library of Victoria]] to [[Parliament House, Melbourne|Parliament House]]. |- |{{flag|Austria}}{{anchor|Austria}} |[[Vienna]] | |2,000 |In Vienna, the capital city, people met in front of the Karlskirche in the first district. The march went through the first district and ended in the Stadtpark. Only one or two hundred people were expected to show, so it was a great shock when two thousand people came to support the movement. Many students from various schools in Vienna made an appearance. Ranging from locale to international schools. There were many signs calling for gender equality, human rights, and LGBTQ+ rights. Some people even took this opportunity to call upon the government to deal with the Syrian refugee crisis, which was currently a problem for Austria and other European countries. |- Saturday night to show their support for women's rights.{{cite news |url=http://emirateswoman.com/women-in-the-middle-east-show-solidarity-with-the-womens-march-on-washington/ |title=Women in the |{{flag|Ireland}}{{anchor|Ireland}} |[[Galway]] | |250–300 |A crowd of around 250 to 300 people gathered in Eyre Square in Galway in the afternoon. Attendees heard calls for a united front to counter the impact of the new US administration.{{Cite news |url=https://www.rte.ie/news/2017/0121/846767-women-marchers-trump/ |title=Women stage massive anti-Trump protests across US |accessdate=January 24, 2017}} |- |[[Dublin]] | |1000s (thousands) |Thousands gathered to march down [[O'Connell Street]]. Though the march was originally planned to conclude with a rally at the [[General Post Office, Dublin|General Post Office]], crowds became so large it had to be moved to [[Parnell Square]].{{Cite web |url=http://evoke.ie/news/world/anti-trump-marches-around-the-globe |title=Millions of women gather around the globe for anti-Trump marches |author=Alison Ring |publisher=evoke.ie |date=2017-01-22 |accessdate=2017-01-25 |quote=Thousands of people turned out in the country’s capital, forcing the demonstration to be moved from the GPO to Parnell Square to cope with the crowds.}} The march was organized by the [[Abortion Rights Campaign]], [[Amnesty International]] Ireland, [[European Network Against Racism]], ROSA,{{Cite web |url=http://rosa.ie/about |title=About ROSA |author= |publisher=ROSA |accessdate=January 24, 2017}} and The Coalition to Repeal [[Eighth Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland|the 8th]], and supported by groups such as the [[National Women's Council of Ireland]] and the [[Union of Students in Ireland]]. Events also took place in [[Castlebar]].{{Cite news |url=http://www.thejournal.ie/trump-womens-march-3198425-Jan2017 |title=Women's March Dublin attracts thousands as part of global protest against Trump |last=Murray |first=Sean |accessdate=January 24, 2017}} |- |{{flag|Israel}}{{anchor|Israel}} |[[Tel Aviv]] | |400–500 |Protestors gathered outside the U.S. Embassy. The local time accommodated the local Sabbath observance as well as the time zone difference. The majority in attendance were [[Aliyah#Aliyah from North America|American Israelis]], along with immigrants from other Anglophone countries and native Israelis. Chanting in Hebrew and English and holding signs, the protests aimed at Trump also included opposition to Israeli Prime Minister [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] and his government's policies, particularly the occupation of the Palestinian territories.{{Citation |first=Judy |title=Hundreds rally in Tel Aviv against Trump, in solidarity with Women's March |date=January 21, 2017 |url=http://www.haaretz.com/us-news/.premium-1.766556 |last1=Maltz |newspaper=Haaretz (English edition online)|access-date=January 22, 2017}} |- | rowspan="2" |{{flag|Italy}}{{anchor|Italy}} |[[Florence]] | | | |- |Rome | |100s (hundreds) |Protesters gathered outside the [[Pantheon, Rome|Pantheon]] in Rome. Their messages included "Women's rights are human rights" and "Yes we must". |- |{{flag|Japan}}{{anchor|Japan}} |Tokyo | |650 |Protestors, mostly [[Expatriate|expats]] and women, marched in Tokyo's [[Hibiya Park]], far exceeding the 150 who registered. The event was organized by Erica Summers, a Los Angeles resident who was traveling abroad at the time of the March of Washington, with assistance from [[Democrats Abroad]].{{cite news |url=http://www.elle.com/culture/career-politics/news/a42322/tokyo-women-march/ |title=While You Were Sleeping, Women Marched in Tokyo |date=January 20, 2017 |work=Elle |accessdate=January 24, 2017 |first=Caitlin |last=Moscatello}} |- |{{flag|Jordan}}{{anchor|Jordan}} |[[Amman]] | |30+ |Women held workshops in the city of Amman to promote women's rights and tolerance. |- |{{flag|Kenya}}{{anchor|Kenya}} |[[Nairobi]] |[[File:Women's March 2017-01 (02).jpg|center|125px]] |700Estimate based on review of video footage of the entire march procession, as seen here: [https://photos.google.com/share/AF1QipND0Ly8aWlRJBUWmRup5ZUA79QsVfdkvscQYJMt4R2HQwapYPjLtOLGmfmVPFl6yw/photo/AF1QipOpX_P_hTWNpUkz51__-1UU1f-pTXBL1teN8HKI?key=Vk5Za3hGUlNpZ3RKM1VraWlKT2ZKaFh5ZXUzTUJn Link] |Women, men and children from Kenya and around the world marched in [[Karura Forest]]{{cite news |url=http://www.voanews.com/a/australia-anti-trump-protests/3686004.html |title=Women Around World Rally in Solidarity With Washington March |date=January 21, 2017 |work=VOA News |accessdate=January 21, 2017 |first=Phil |last=Mercer}} to support women's rights, human rights and social justice, and in solidarity with the nearly 700 other Sister Marches around the world. Marchers mobilized to make demands of the Kenyan government, while also calling on the new US government and governments around the world to reject policies that limit women's rights.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} The march was endorsed by a wide range of Kenyan and international civil society organizations including the Amnesty International Kenya, the Centre for Rights Awareness and Education (CREAW), the Coalition for Grassroots Human Rights Defenders, the Coalition on Violence Against Women (COVAW), the Gay and Lesbian Coalition of Kenya, Her Voice Kenya, Human Rights Watch, the Kenya Human Rights Commission, Kenya Sex Worker Alliance (KESWA), Minority Women in Action, the National Gay and Lesbian Human Rights Commission (NGLHRC), and the World March of Women – Kenya Chapter.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} |- |{{flag|Kosovo}}{{anchor|Kosovo}} |[[Pristina]] | |100s (hundreds) |In Pristina, capital of the largely Muslim former Yugoslav republic of Kosovo, a few hundred protestors, mostly women, joined a protest against the new Trump administration. |- |{{flag|Latvia}}{{anchor|Latvia}} |Riga | |200{{Cite news |url=http://www.lsm.lv/en/article/politics/women-march-against-trump-in-riga.a220203/ |title=Women march against Trump in Riga|access-date=January 23, 2017}} |In Riga, the capital of Latvia, approximately 200 people gathered to march from the Polish Gate through the Old Town, ending at the Freedom Monument.{{Cite news |url=http://bnn-news.com/photo-women-s-solidarity-march-in-riga-158947/nggallery/page/2 |title=PHOTO: women's solidarity march in Riga |date=January 23, 2017 |publisher=Baltic News Network – News from Latvia, Lithuania, Estonia |accessdate=January 24, 2017}} |- |{{flag|Lebanon}}{{anchor|Lebanon}} |[[Beirut]] | |30+ |A women-led event consisting of dialogue and action workshops was held in Lebanon in lieu of a public rally. |- |{{flag|Lithuania}}{{anchor|Lithuania}} |Vilnius | |120 |Approximately 120 people attended Sister March Vilnius.{{Cite news |url=http://www.delfi.lt/news/daily/lithuania/vilniuje-vyko-eitynes-pries-smurta.d?id=73514106 |title=Women march against Violence in Vilnius |date=January 23, 2017 |publisher=DELFI |language=lt-LT|access-date=January 24, 2017}} |- |{{flag|Macau}}{{anchor|Macau}} |[[Macau]] | |100 |Groups of people gathering around Estrada da Baía de N. Senhora da Esperança in Taipa, Macau. |- |{{flag|Malawi}}{{anchor|Malawi}} |[[Lilongwe]] | | | |- |rowspan="1" |{{flag|Mexico}}{{anchor|Mexico}} |[[Mexico City]] | |100s (hundreds){{cite news |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/wireStory/womens-marches-attract-masses-globe-44950272 |title=From London to LA, Women's Marches Pack Cities Big and Small |first1=Sara |last1=Burnett |first2=Gregory |last2=Katz |date=January 21, 2017 |work=ABC News |accessdate=January 23, 2017}} |A demonstration was held at the [[Embassy of the United States, Mexico City|United States Embassy]], followed by a large march went from to the [[Angel of Independence]] by Mexicans and Americans, who protested against President Trump and Mexican President [[Enrique Peña Nieto]], who has only a 12% approval rating. They called for gender equality and women's rights.Dwyer, Colin and Maggie Penman, Mandalit del Barco, Frank Langfitt. [https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/01/21/510940708/womens-march-on-washington-goes-worldwide-snapshots-from-around-the-globe Women's Marches Go Global: Postcards From Protests Around The World] (January 21, 2017). NPR; retrieved January 24, 2017. |- |{{flag|Myanmar}}{{anchor|Myanmar}} (Burma) |[[Yangon]] (Rangoon) | |data-sort-value=1 |Dozens |Because political circumstances would not permit a march, dozens of people instead attended a "solidarity picnic".{{cite news |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/womens-march-washington-chicago-massive-turnout-change-of-plans/ |title=Massive Women's March turnouts prompt change of plans in D.C., Chicago |date=January 21, 2017 |publisher=CBS News |accessdate=January 23, 2017}} |- | rowspan="2" |{{flag|Netherlands}}{{anchor|Netherlands}} |[[Amsterdam]] |[[File:Amsterdam Women's March L1003135-Edit (32399726686).jpg|center|125px]] |3,000{{cite news |url=http://www.rtlnieuws.nl/nederland/3000-demonstranten-bij-protestactie-womens-march-in-amsterdam |title=3000 demonstranten bij protestactie Women's March in Amsterdam |date=January 21, 2017 |work=RTL Nieuws |language=Dutch|access-date=January 21, 2017}} | |- |[[The Hague]] | |100s (hundreds)de Volkskrant: [http://www.volkskrant.nl/binnenland/nederlanders-tegen-trump-na-amerika-zijn-wij-aan-de-beurt-met-wilders~a4451736/ Cookiewall: Cookies op de Volkskrant | de Volkskrant], accessdate: January 23, 2017 |Protestors walked from Maliveld to the US Embassy. |- | rowspan="3" |{{flag|New Zealand}}{{anchor|New Zealand}} |[[Auckland]] |[[File:Womens March Auckland 2017 Myers Park.jpg|center|125px]] |2,000 |Because of time differences, the first marches held were in New Zealand. Around 300 to 400 protesters reportedly also attended rallies in [[Christchurch]], [[Dunedin]] and [[Invercargill]].{{Cite news |url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/national/322798/nz-leads-marches-for-women's-rights |title=NZ leads marches for women's rights |date=January 20, 2017 |work=Radio New Zealand |accessdate=January 21, 2017}}{{cite web |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/88642615/new-zealand-leads-global-marches-in-defence-of-womens-rights-after-donald-trumps-inauguration |title=New Zealand leads global marches in defence of women's rights after Donald Trump's inauguration |website=Stuff|access-date=January 22, 2017}} |- |[[Dunedin]] | |400{{cite web marches in over 75 countries |date=January 20, 2017 |publisher=PRI.org |accessdate=January 21, 2017}} |- |{{flag|Norway}}{{anchor|Norway}} |[[Oslo]] | |2,000 |Likewise, hundreds of people marched in
