[[File:Il salone è mobile color chairs.jpg|thumb|Coloured chair exhibit at Salone 2009]] The '''Milan Furniture Fair''' ({{lang-it|Salone Internazionale del Mobile di Milano}}) is a [[furniture]] fair held annually in [[Milan]]. It is the largest [[trade fair]] of its kind in the world. The exhibition showcases the latest in furniture and design from countries around the world. It is considered a leading venue for the display of new products by [[designers]] of furniture, lighting and other home furnishings. The show, also known as "Salone", "Milano Salone" and "Milan Design Week," is held every year, usually in April, in the [[FieraMilano]] complex in the [[Milan metropolitan area]] town of [[Rho, Italy|Rho]].<ref name=cosmit>{{cite web|url=http://www.cosmit.it/tool/home.php?s=0,2,69,93 |title=Cosmit - Salone Internazionale del Mobile di Milano |publisher=Cosmit.it |date= |accessdate=2012-01-01}}</ref>
== History == [[File:Lago stand in Salone del mobile 2008.jpg|thumb|Exhibitor display at Salone 2008]] The Salone Internazionale del Mobile di Milano was launched in 1961, with the original focus being Italian furniture.<ref name="nytimes1">[https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/18/arts/18iht-design18.html?pagewanted=all Milan's Furniture Whirlwind]</ref> The original sponsors were furniture manufacturers from the Federelegno-Arredo trade association.<ref name=cosmit/> The trade show grew in size over the years, allowing many of the 13,000 companies which comprised the global [[furniture industry]] to showcase their wares in a single event.<ref name=cosmit/>
The current show occupies an area of nearly {{convert|230000|m2}}, and includes 2,500 companies, along with 700 young designers at the Salone Satellite, a secondary exhibit.<ref name=cosmit/> The show's annual visitation numbers 270,000, with attendees from over 150 countries worldwide.<ref name=cosmit/> The show is now organized and operated by Cosmit [[Società per Azioni|S.p.A.]], a trade show corporation and a member of the ICSID ([[International Council of Societies of Industrial Design]]) and ADI (Association for Industrial Design). Interior design around the world gathers at Milan in April every year at Milan Design Week commonly known as Salone Internazionale del Mobile covered online at designers such as designerzcentral.<ref name=cosmit/>
In 2011, there were 2,720 exhibitors at the official fair, compared to 2,499 in 2010. New lighting technologies at the show included the Flos 2620 LED chandelier with 2,620 LEDs in what appeared to be random rings of light arranged to create the illusion of movement. The standpoint piece for Arco, a 106-year-old Dutch company, was the wooden furniture produced by the [[Israel]]i designer Shay Alkalay. Of the student shows, the Dutch design school [[Design Academy Eindhoven]] took first place, followed by Israel's [[Bezalel Academy of Art and Design]].<ref name="nytimes1"/> Also, some early examples of the combination of [[sustainability]] and design were showcased, which eventually resulted in a [[United Kingdom|British]] entrepreneurial initiative a few years later, pioneer of the upcoming sustainable design revolution.<ref>http://hear.ceoblognation.com/2013/06/03/why-did-you-start-your-business-2/ Ashley Poulter, Editor for CEO Blog Nation writes for Hearpreneur.com, 2 June 2013,</ref>
In year 2018, the 57th edition of the Salone del Mobile.Milano, there were 434,509 visitors in 6 days from 188 different countries. To compare the year 2016 and 2017, it has increased 17% and 26%. <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.elledecor.com/it/best-of/a20683458/milano-design-week-2018-attendance-performance-eng/|title=MILANO DESIGN WEEK 2018: LET’S TALK NUMBERS|last=|first=|date=2018-05-29|website=Elle DECOR Italia|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== See also ==

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2017}} {{Use Indian English|date=May 2017}} {{Infobox film | name = Mogul | image = | alt = | director = Jai Sharma | producer =[[Bhushan Kumar]]
Krishan Kumar | writer = | starring = [[Rajkummar Rao]]
[[Mouni Roy]]
[[Vikram Gokhale]] | studio = [[Super Cassettes Industries T-Series|T-Series]] | released = Christmas 2019 | country = India | language = [[Hindi]] | budget = | gross = }} '''''Mogul''''' is an upcoming 2019 Indian [[biographical film]]. It is produced by [[Bhushan Kumar]] of [[T-Series (company)|T-Series]], and follows the life of the mogul [[Gulshan Kumar]] who was founder of the [[Super Cassettes Industries T-Series|T-Series]] [[music label]] ([[Super Cassettes Industries|Super Cassettes Industries Ltd.]]), and a [[Bollywood]] film producer.[http://www.atimes.com/atimes/South_Asia/FE29Df05.html]{{dead link|date=July 2017}}[http://www.bollywoodmascot.com/akshay-kumar-upcoming-bollywood-movies-2018-2019] The film is set to release in Christmas 2019.{{cite web|last=Tamta |first=Devesh |url=http://www.ilubilu.com/akshay-kumar-upcoming-movies.html|title=Akshay Kumar Upcoming Movies & Release date 2017, 2018 & 19|website=Ilubilu.com|date=2017-06-22|accessdate=2017-07-16}} The film initially starred [[Aamir Khan]] as Kumar.{{cite web|url=https://www.hindustantimes.com/bollywood/accused-of-molestation-director-subash-kapoor-says-he-respects-aamir-khan-s-decision-to-quit-his-film/story-UaH0cGvQ3buOTluQrFciON.html|title=Aamir Khan decides to quit Mogul|website=hindustantimes.com|date=2018-10-11|accessdate=2018-10-11}} In October 2018, amid molestation allegations against [[Subhash Kapoor]], [[Aamir Khan]] and [[Kiran Rao]] who were the co-producers of the film decided to quit the project.{{cite web|url=https://www.ndtv.com/entertainment/after-aamir-khan-steps-away-from-film-subhash-kapoor-dropped-as-mogul-director-1930302|title=Aamir Khan and Kiran Rao quit Mogul|website=ndtv.com|date=2018-10-11|accessdate=2018-10-11}} Producer Bhushan Kumar then dropped Kapoor from the project.{{cite news |title=Post Aamir Khan's decision to 'step away' from Mogul, co-producer Bhushan Kumar drops director Subhash Kapoor |url=https://www.timesnownews.com/entertainment/news/bollywood-news/article/post-aamir-khans-decision-to-step-away-from-mogul-co-producer-bhushan-kumar-drops-director-subhash-kapoor/297493 |publisher=Times Now |date=11 October 2018}} ==Cast== * [[Rajkummar Rao]] as [[Gulshan Kumar]] * [[Gulshan Grover]] as [[Dawood Ibrahim]] * [[Mouni Roy]] * [[Vikram Gokhale]] * Abdul Quadir Amin{{Cite web|url=https://www.cinestaan.com/movies/mogul-24947|title=Mogul (2018) - Review, Star Cast, News, Photos {{!}} Cinestaan|website=Cinestaan|access-date=2018-07-30}} ==References== {{Reflist}} revision.comment: /* See also */
revision.text:
{{Infobox music festival | name =Music Tech Fest | image = File:Music_Tech_Fest.jpg | caption = | location =[[Wellington]], [[Boston]], [[London]], [[Berlin]], [[Paris]], [[Umeå]] and [[Ljubljana]] | years_active = | founders =Michela Magas | dates =2012-present | genre = [[Electronic music]], etc. | attendance = | capacity = | website =[http://musictechfest.org Music Tech Fest official site] }}
'''Music Tech Fest''' (MTF) is a three-day [[arts festival]] and creative space where participants share and "develop new formats of musical performance and expression." It is billed as the 'festival of music ideas'.
MTF presents technological innovations and artistic experimentation, performance, new inventions, commercial applications, and academic research.
Music Tech Fest events are streamed live online, and videos of individual presentations are made available on YouTube.
The festival runs a 24-hour weekend hackathon and an academic symposium known as the 'afterparty' on the Monday following the weekend's event. At the Boston afterparty, participants collaborated on the composition of a ''Manifesto for the Future of Music Technology Research''.<ref>[http://www.musictechifesto.org Manifesto for the Future of Music Technology Research].</ref>
==History== Music Tech Fest began as result of the [http://mires.cc/files/MIRES_Roadmap_ver_1.0.0.pdf Roadmap for Music Information Research] (MIReS),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mires.cc|title=MIReS - >>> the future of music tech|work=mires.cc}}</ref> a European [[Framework Programmes for Research and Technological Development#FP6 and FP7|FP7]] project run by seven European research centers: [[Music Technology Group]] at the [[Universitat Pompeu Fabra]] in Barcelona; [http://www.stromatolite.com Stromatolite]; [[OFAI]], Austrian Research Institute for Artificial Intelligence, Vienna, Austria; [http://www.inesctec.pt INESCP], Instituto de Engenharia de Sistemas e Computadores, Porto, Portugal; [[IRCAM]] at the [[Centre Pompidou]] in Paris; Centre for Digital Music (C4DM), Queen Mary, University of London, UK; and Barcelona Music and Audio Technology (BMAT), Barcelona, Spain.
The project's Scientific Director Michela Magas of Stromatolite launched the first Music Tech Fest event in London 2012 as a way to bring academics and practitioners together. The first festival included contributions from [[EMI]], [[BBC]], [[Spotify]], [[Soundcloud]] and [[Shazam (service)|Shazam]] as well as academic researchers, makers, developers and artists. MTF London 2012 featured 54 performers and presenters, 70 hackers and 70 creatives.{{citation needed|date=March 2015}}
In May 2013 the festival ran again in London with the additional involvement of all of the major record labels. In September of that year, Professor Andrew Dubber from [[Birmingham City University]] joined as festival director. In 2014, the festival went on tour with events in [[Wellington]], [[Boston]], [[London]], [[Berlin]] and [[Paris]]. In 2015 festival organisers scheduled larger regional events, rather than focusing on individual cities: MTF Scandinavia in [[Umeå]] and MTF Central Europe in [[Ljubljana]].{{citation needed|date=March 2015}}
Starting with 2015, the Music Tech Fest is supported by the EU [[Horizon 2020]] project ''MusicBricks'' which aims at fostering creative development of new ideas around music technology and supporting pilots which lead to market prototypes. This opens the pathway to reach a wider community of creative SME innovators.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://musichackday.upf.edu/mhd/2015/?p=73|title=» The European project #MusicBricks will run a creative testbed pilot during the hacking session|work=upf.edu}}</ref>
==Hack Camp== Music Tech Fest supports the growing [[Hacker (programmer subculture)|hack culture]], and promotes it as an important source of creativity. The festival holds its own [[hackathon]] at each festival, MTF Hack Camp, which runs for 24 hours from Saturday afternoon to Sunday.<ref name="bbc.co.uk">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-27062533|title=BBC News - Hackathon brings new instruments and sounds to life|work=BBC News}}</ref> Like [[Music Hack Day]] events, the MTF hack camp focuses on music-related hack challenges, but with a particular focus on performance with tangible objects, physical concepts and new integrations between [[software]] and [[Electronic hardware|hardware]]. There are competitions held at each MTF hack camp where individuals and groups work in response to particular challenges that reflect the themes of each festival. MTF hack camp challenges have engaged with ideas of accessibility (London 2014), fashion and wearables (Paris 2014), and creative spaces (Berlin 2014).
The festivals in London and Umeå also involve a Kids Hack which Andrew Dubber discussed in an interview for WebTVspot as an 'opportunity for families and young people to get involved'.<ref>http://www.vk.se/tv?video=3beca3e9-dc2b-4a17-95c5-ad30a52cb47b</ref> The MTF website and YouTube pages show performances from the Kids Hack, of participants presenting simple gestural controllers and instruments. Some of the older 'hackers' showed some more complex projects including a remote controlled Tricopter with a camera which was connected to some video goggles to navigate and film the Tricopters flight.<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-Ssk3RKOJgY</ref>
==Festival contributors== Contributors to the festival have included: [[IRCAM]], The [[London Symphony Orchestra]], [[Soundcloud]], [[Mixcloud]], The [[BBC]], [[EMI]], [[RCA Records]], [[Shazam (service)|Shazam]], [[Last.fm]], [[Ableton]], [[Native Instruments]], [[Izotope]], [[FXpansion]], [[RS Components]], [[RjDj]], [[WIRED]], [[MTV]], [[Microsoft Research]], [[Cisco]], [[Stephen Fry]]/[[Penguin (publisher)|Penguin]], [[EU Commission]], [[DMIC]], [[British Council]], [[Sound and Music]], [[Modern Times Group|MTG]], [[Fraunhofer Society]], [[Cantonal and University Library of Lausanne|BCU]], [[MIT Media Lab]], [[Berklee College of Music]], [[McGill University|McGill]], [[Goldsmiths]], [[Royal College of Art]], [[Ninja Tune]], [[Warp (record label)|Warp]], [[The Echo Nest]], [[MusicBrainz]], [[Reactable]], [[Jamie Cullum]], [[Tim Exile]], [[Leafcutter John]].{{citation needed|date=March 2015}}
==Media coverage== * The Next Web on How the first Music Tech Fest explored the future of sound<ref>{{cite web|url=https://thenextweb.com/uk/2012/05/20/musical-ping-pong-and-hacked-lightsabers-how-the-first-music-tech-fest-explored-the-future-of-sound/|title=A Round Up of the First Music Tech Fest in London|author=Jamillah Knowles|date=20 May 2012|work=The Next Web}}</ref> * [[BBC Click]] has covered Music Tech Fest events in Boston<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-27067106|title=BBC News - Hacking the instrument of the future in Boston|work=BBC News}}</ref> and London.<ref name="bbc.co.uk"/> * [[Radio New Zealand National]] covered Music Tech Fest Wellington<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/national/programmes/nat-music/audio/2587487/music-tech-day-2014|title=Music Tech Fest 2014|date=1 March 2014|work=Radio New Zealand}}</ref> * [[Boston Herald]] covered Music Tech Fest Boston<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bostonherald.com/business/technology/technology_news/2014/03/hub_hosts_fest_on_music_tech|title=Hub hosts fest on music tech|author=Jordan Graham|work=bostonherald.com}}</ref> * [[France 24]] reported on Music Tech Fest Paris<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20141128-tech24-Music-Tech-Fest-Paris-2014/|title=#TECH 24 - What does the future hold... for music? - France 24|work=France 24}}</ref> * [[Microsoft]] New England: Music Tech Fest Hits Cambridge This Weekend – Let's Invent the Future of Music<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.microsoftnewengland.com/2014/03/19/music-tech-fest-hits-cambridge-this-weekend-lets-invent-the-future-of-music/|title=Music Tech Fest Hits Cambridge This Weekend – Let’s Invent the Future of Music|work=microsoftnewengland.com}}</ref> * Electronic Sound Magazine covered MTF Scandinavia<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.electronicsound.co.uk/show-your-tech-idea-in-sweden/|title=SHOW YOUR TECH IDEA IN SWEDEN|work=electronicsound.co.uk}}</ref> *Production Advice covered Music Tech Fest London 2014<ref>{{cite web|url=http://productionadvice.co.uk/music-tech-fest-review/|title=Music Tech Fest – 100% inspirational|work=productionadvice.co.uk}}</ref> *Sound Stuff covered Music Tech Fest London 2014<ref>{{cite web|url=https://soundnoticeboard.wordpress.com/2014/09/06/recommending-the-mtflondon-music-tech-fest-with-a-music-hack-for-8-16-yo-tomorrow-old-st/|title=Recommending the #mtflondon (Music Tech Fest) – with a music hack for 8-16 yo tomorrow (Old St)|work=soundnoticeboard.wordpress.com}}</ref> *Openstage covered Music Tech Fest London 2013<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.openstageit.com/music-tech-fest/|title=Music Tech Fest|work=openstageit.com}}</ref> *Startsida covered Music Tech Fest Scandinavia<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.umea.se/arkiv/nyheter/toppartiklar/musictechfesttillumeaimaj.5.65771eb14bfe25fed220527.html|title=Music Tech Fest till Umeå i maj|work=umea.se}}</ref> *The 405 covered an interview with Festival Director Andrew Dubber following Music Tech Fest London 2013<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefourohfive.com/music/news/article/the-405-meets-music-tech-fest-s-andrew-dubber-140|title=The 405 meets Music Tech Fest's Andrew Dubber|work=thefourohfive.com}}</ref> *Startacus covered MTF London<ref>{{cite web|url=https://startacus.net/culture/music-tech-fest#.VZqnPVyFG0s|title=Music Tech Fest|work=startacus.net}}</ref> *Re-compose covered Music Tech Fest Scandinavia<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.re-compose.com/new-music-formats-at-music-tech-fest-scandinavia.html|title=New formats take centre stage at Music Tech Fest Scandinavia|work=re-compose.com}}</ref> *Sandbox Education covered Kids Hacks in London<ref name="sandboxeducation.co.uk">{{cite web|url=http://sandboxeducation.co.uk/music-tech-fest-at-the-lso/|title=MTF London - Kids Hack Presentation|work=sandboxeducation.co.uk}}</ref> and Umeå<ref name="sandboxeducation.co.uk"/> *Umeå University covered Music Tech Fest Scandinavia<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.umu.se/english/about-umu/news-events/news/newsdetailpage/music-tech-fest-scandinavia-at-sliperiet-.cid252463|title=Music Tech Fest Scandinavia at Sliperiet|work=umu.se}}</ref> *DesignSpark, RS Components covered Music Tech Fest London 2014<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rs-online.com/designspark/electronics/eng/blog/music-tech-fest|title=Music Tech Fest|work=rs-online.com}}</ref> *Protein covered Music Tech Fest Scandinavia<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.prote.in/en/feed/2015/05/inventing-the-future-of-music|title=Inventing the future of music|work=prote.in}}</ref> *Västerbottens-Kuriren published a TV interview with Festival Director Andrew Dubber in preparation for Music Tech Fest Scandinavia<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vk.se/play?video=3beca3e9-dc2b-4a17-95c5-ad30a52cb47b|title=Music Tech Fest kommer till Umeå|work=vk.se}}</ref> *Creative Works London covered Music Tech Fest London 2014<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.creativeworkslondon.org.uk/cw-news/music-tech-fest-london-2014-5-7-september-2014/|title=MUSIC TECH FEST LONDON 2014 (5 – 7 SEPTEMBER 2014)|work=creativeworkslondon.org.uk}}</ref> *Perlimpinpin Designers covered Music Tech Fest London 2014<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ppp-designers.co.uk/blog/2014/09/08/music-tech-festival-london/|title=The Music Tech Festival in London|work=ppp-designers.co.uk}}</ref> *Nialler9 covered Music Tech Fest London 2014<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nialler9.com/music-tech-fest-hits-london-next-week/|title=Music Tech Fest hits London next week|work=nialler9.com}}</ref>
==MTF Scandinavia== MTF Scandinavia took place in [[Umeå]] [[Sweden]] from the 29–31 May 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kitmonsters.com/blog/music-tech-fest-from-paris-to-sweden|title=Music Tech Fest from Paris to Sweden|work=kitmonsters.com.com}}</ref> The festival included presentations and performances from Jon Eades from Abbey Road Red, [[Abbey Road]]'s new technology and innovation incubator, electronic artist Scanner, [[Robin Rimbaud]] and founder of English electronic group [[808 State]], [[Graham Massey]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://musictechfest.org/scandischedule/|title=Music Tech Fest Scandi Schedule|work=musictechfest.org}}</ref>
The 24hr Hack Camp had four hack challenges of which there were seven winning teams. Each challenge reflected the values and ideas spread by MTF; the 'Music Things for Music Ecosystems' and 'The Sound Objects in Smart Homes' challenge connected with ideas of collaboration and the Internet of Things, IoT. The Cymatics Challenge aimed to explore the relationships between sonic and visual art through this interdisciplinary medium. The final challenge from MTF Scandinavia was the 'Music as Communication' which focused on music tools that were communicative and accessible. Four winning teams used the #MusicBricks technologies which, led to the funding and incubation of their projects to develop them further.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://us7.campaign-archive1.com/?u=2fff492682fa89054a14e8980&id=cbdc594fdb&e=6ff253a722|title=#MusicBricks: 8 new startup ideas with half a million social reach}}</ref> Incubation was also awarded to the two winning hacks from the 'Music Things for Music Ecosystems' and 'Music as Communication' prizes from Umeå based incubators eXpression, and the final winning Cymatics team were awarded the materials to help with future endeavours.
The [[Volvo]] Kids Hack ran on Sunday morning 10:00-12:00, led by Siobhan Ramsey of Sandbox Education, with presentations on stage in the afternoon at 14:00. Young Hackers, aged between 8-12 used tools from [[Arduino]] and Bare Conductive to create interactive instruments and musical interfaces.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sandboxeducation.co.uk/sandbox-education-youth-hack-at-the-music-tech-fest/|title=Sandbox Education Youth Hack at the Music Tech Fest|work=sandboxeducation.co.uk}}</ref>
MTF Scandinavia also included two new editions, a Jam Camp which lasted the duration of the festival and a Trackathon which ran for a week. The Jam Camp, led by Obi Blanche, was a space for people to try out music technology and play together.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.prote.in/en/feed/2015/05/inventing-the-future-of-music|title=Inventing the Future of Music|work=prote.in}}</ref> This culminated in a Jam performance on stage on the final night of the festival. The trackathon was sponsored by [[EZdrummer|Toontrack]] and was a competition to create a track using the [[EZdrummer|Toontrack]] drum packages.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UVroo9zQz1Y&index=13&list=PLF3eM81pDgI3eqEnVJEP0rpS82Uk__Ef-|title=#MTFScandi Live Jam - MTF Allstars|work=youtube.com}}</ref> The two winners of the challenge, CJ Carr and Matan Berkowitz had their tracks mastered and released on [[Bandcamp]] by members of the judging panel including Vince Lynch, Pascal Guyon and Phonat (Michele Balduzzi).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://musictechfest.org/toontrack-trackathon-winners/|title=Toontrack Trackathon Winners|work=musictechfest.org}}</ref> All money raised went to a charity supporting artists suffering from depression.
MTF Scandinavia was held at Sliperiet - a co-creative space in [[Umeå Arts Campus]] where MTF is based, alongside many other creative enterprises.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.umu.se/ViewPage.action?siteNodeId=4510&languageId=1&contentId=252463|title=Music Tech Fest Scandinavia at Sliperiet|work=umu.se}}</ref> Throughout the weekend, organisations from Sliperiet put on sound installations around the upper floors of the building. These included ‘The Voice Harvester’ by Swedish ICT Interactive,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tii.se|title=Swedish ICT Interactive|work=tii.se}}</ref> ‘Audification of Absence’ by Willem Zwagers,<ref>Willem Zwagers</ref> and ‘Bubble Room Instrument’, ‘Bridging Realities Collaborative’, ‘Untitled 5:22mins’ and ‘Silent Forest’ by JAQ. There were also two installations on the ground floor from outside of Sliperiet; James Brewster’s Electro Acoustic Cafe,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.electro-acoustic-cafe.com/about.htm|title=Electro Acoustic Cafe|work=electro-acoustic-cafe.com}}</ref> and ‘The Worlds Biggest Midi Controller’ by Hakan Lidbo.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hakanlidbo.com/archives/3657|title=Big Cubes|work=hakanlidbo.com}}</ref>
There was also a gamification workshop on Saturday, which led to the development of the CreaCity platform for the city of Umeå, [[Sweden]]. CreaCity was released as part of the European SPECIFI project to develop tools for engagement with city culture and local businesses.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ficG_PGXR7k|title=#MTFScandi: Alexandra Antonopoulou - Creative Ring Workshop|work=youtube.com}}</ref>
Sponsors and partners of MTF Scandinavia include; 4Sound, Bare Conductive, Beer Studio, Costas of Sweden, Electronic Sound, Drake Music, [[Guitars – the Museum]], Hansson & Hammar, HUMlab Umeå, Kulturverket, Jays, Kitmonsters, Laser Unicorns, Musikanten, Sliperiet Umeå Universitet, [[Sonos]], Soundation, [[SoundCloud]], [[Spendrups]], [[Swedbank]], [[Teenage Engineering]], Tiljan, [[EZdrummer|Toontrack]], U & Me Hotel, [[Umeå University]], Umeå kommun, [[Umeå Energi|Umenet]], Uminova Innovation, Uminova eXpression, Visit Umeå, [[Volvo]], [[Warner Music Group]], topi, YNK Produktion, [[Ninja Tune]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://musictechfest.org/mtfscandi/|title=#MTFScandi|work=musictechfest.org}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Hackathon]] * [[Music Hack Day]] * [[Upcoming Music Festival at Stockholm on 7 - 9 September 2018]] [https://musictechfest.net/ Book Tickets!]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * {{official website|http://musictechfest.org}} * [https://www.youtube.com/musictechfest Music Tech Fest YouTube channel] * [http://musictechfest.tumblr.com Music Tech Fest at Tumblr (featuring previous Music Hacks)]

revision.comment: /* The views of the respective parties */
revision.text:
{{POV-check|date=August 2016}} [[File:Srusena televizija 2.JPG|Razed building of TVNS in [[Mišeluk]]|thumb|280px]]
During the [[1999 NATO bombing of the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|1999 NATO bombing of Yugoslavia]], the second largest Yugoslav city of [[Novi Sad]] was one of the cities that bore the brunt of the bombing. According to NATO press releases, {{ref|NATO}} the bombing targeted oil refineries, roads, bridges, and telecommunications relay stations, facilities which had military uses. The bombing of the city caused great damage to local [[civilian]]s, including severe pollution and widespread [[Environmental degradation|ecological damage]] as well as lasting consequences for the well being of the population.
==Chronology of the bombing== {{Campaignbox Kosovo War}} *March 24: NATO bombed a storehouse of the police center in the industrial zone, as well as the "Motins" factory. [[File:Нато бомбама срушио Варадински мост.jpeg|thumb|right|Varadin Bridge destroyed.]] *April 1: The old Varadin Bridge on the [[Danube]] was destroyed by NATO bombs. *April 3: [[Liberty Bridge (Novi Sad)|Liberty Bridge]] on the Danube was destroyed by NATO bombs. Seven civilians were injured. After the bridge was destroyed, the institute for cardio-vascular diseases in [[Sremska Kamenica]] lost its water supply. *April 5: NATO bombed the oil refinery in the industrial zone, as well as [[Žeželj Bridge]] on the Danube, which was damaged. *April 7: NATO bombed the oil refinery as well as the residential civilian quarter [[Vidovdansko Naselje]] where four civilians were injured and several houses damaged. *April 11: NATO bombed the military object "Majevica" in [[Jugovićevo]]. *April 13: NATO bombed the oil refinery. *April 15: NATO bombed the oil refinery and the military object "Majevica" in Jugovićevo. *April 18: NATO bombed the oil refinery which triggered a large fire and much smoke, which caused serious ecological damage. The building of the Government of the Autonomous Province of [[Vojvodina]] in the [[Stari Grad, Novi Sad|city centre]] was also hit by NATO bombs. *April 21: NATO bombed the oil refinery and Žeželj Bridge, as well as a bridge near [[Beška]]. [[File:Жежељев мост свакодневно су погађале ракете типа Томахавк.jpeg|thumb|right|Žeželj Bridge damaged in first attack.]] *April 22: NATO bombed Žeželj Bridge on the Danube. *April 23: NATO bombed a TV transmitter in wider area of Novi Sad. *April 24: NATO bombed the oil refinery causing fire and smoke. [[Fruška Gora]] was also bombed. *April 26: NATO finally managed to destroy Žeželj Bridge, the last bridge on the Danube that the city had. [[File:Скела на Дунаву током НАТО бомбардовања 1999 године.jpeg|thumb|right|With all bridges destroyed, Novi Sad residents were forced to cross Danube with an army pontoon ferry.]]
*April 27: NATO bombed the oil refinery and Fruška Gora. *April 29: NATO bombed the oil refinery and Fruška Gora. *May 1: NATO bombed the oil refinery causing large amounts of smoke that covered the city for several days. Fruška Gora was also bombed. *May 2: NATO bombed the northern suburbs of Novi Sad causing the city to lose its water supply and electricity. *May 3: NATO bombed the buildings of Novi Sad Television in [[Mišeluk]] as well as the northern suburbs of the city. *May 6: NATO bombed the military object "Majevica" in Jugovićevo as well as the civilian residential quarter [[Detelinara]] damaging residential buildings. *May 7: NATO bombed [[Iriški Venac]] and [[Brankovac]] on Fruška Gora. *May 8: NATO bombed the military object "Majevica" in Jugovićevo and Fruška Gora. *May 13: NATO bombed the buildings of Novi Sad Television in Mišeluk. Its buildings were heavily damaged as well as neighbouring civilian residential houses. Fruška Gora was also bombed, as well as electric installations in [[Rimski Šančevi]] causing the city to lose electricity again. *May 15: NATO bombed Brankovac on Fruška Gora. *May 18: NATO bombed Fruška Gora. *May 20: NATO bombed Fruška Gora. *May 22: NATO bombed Fruška Gora including a TV tower on Iriški Venac. *May 23: NATO bombed Fruška Gora and electric installations in Rimski Šančevi. *May 24: NATO bombed the oil refinery causing smoke that again covered part of the city. Fruška Gora was also bombed. *May 26: NATO bombed buildings of the Novi Sad Television in Mišeluk, as well as Dunavski Kej (Danube Quay) near the city centre. [[Paragovo]], Iriški Venac on Fruška Gora and small barrack in [[Bukovac, Novi Sad|Bukovac]] were also bombed. *May 29: NATO bombed buildings of the Novi Sad Television as well as the civilian residential quarter [[Ribnjak, Novi Sad|Ribnjak]] where two civilians were badly injured. *May 30: NATO bombed the civilian residential area in [[Sremska Kamenica]] near an ambulance where one child was badly injured and two civilian houses were destroyed. The civilian residential area Ribnjak was also bombed as well as buildings of the Novi Sad Television, a tunnel near the previously destroyed Liberty Bridge, a road near the entrance to Sremska Kamenica, part of Fruška Gora between Paragovo and Krušedol, and the northern vicinity of Novi Sad. *May 31: NATO bombed electric installations in Rimski Šančevi causing the city to lose its water supply and electricity. Fruška Gora was also bombed. *June 1: NATO bombed suburban settlements [[Čenej]] and [[Pejićevi Salaši]], as well as Fruška Gora. *June 2: NATO bombed Fruška Gora. *June 4: NATO bombed Brankovac and [[Čot]] on Fruška Gora. *June 8 and June 9: NATO bombed the oil refinery, one civilian was killed, while two civilians and one child were badly injured. The civilian residential quarter [[Šangaj]] was also bombed where one civilian, Milan Bajić (42 years old), was killed and several more civilians were injured, while several civilian houses were destroyed. Although, this was the bloodiest day of the bombing, it was also the last.
==Consequences== [[File:Бомбардовање СР Југославије 1999.jpeg|thumb|right|NATO missile hit the area between two apartment buildings and elementary school "Svetozar Marković Toza".]]
===Impact on civilians=== The civilians of Novi Sad were greatly affected by the bombing of their city. The city's oil refinery was bombarded daily, causing severe pollution and widespread ecological damage.
====Direct impact==== The bombing caused civilian deaths and injuries. Those who were not directly physically harmed suffer from consequences for their physical health caused by ecological damage as well as permanent consequences for psychological health caused by almost 3 months of trauma and fear. Due to the NATO attacks, many in Novi Sad were left jobless.
Notably, NATO were accused of failing to give "effective advance warning" of attacks which may affect civilians, as required by Protocol I.<ref>[http://mondediplo.com/2000/07/02kosovo]</ref> One such attack where NATO was accused of this was the bombing of the Ministry of Education in Novi Sad, premises which administered social welfare programmes.<ref> [http://www.greenparty.org.uk/files/reports/2004/Yugowar%20for%20website.htm]</ref>
====Impact on infrastructure==== [[File:Нато авијација срушила Мост слободе на Дунаву у Новом Саду.jpeg|thumb|right|[[Liberty Bridge, Novi Sad|Liberty Bridge]] destroyed in NATO air strike.]] The NATO bombing left the city without any of its three Danube bridges, communications, water, and electricity, which severely impaired the day to day living of the residents of Novi Sad. All three bridges have been rebuilt as of 2018 [[Žeželj Bridge]].
Water supplies (including drinking water) for parts of the city were cut off as a result of the bombing. One attack cut off water supplies to 40,000 people in Petrovaradin, and severely disrupted water supplies to 300,000 people in Novi Sad.<ref>[http://www.greenparty.org.uk/files/reports/2004/Yugowar%20for%20website.htm]</ref> Services were restored only after two years, partially due to funding from Britain, one of the countries which bombed targets in the city in 1999.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/1318455.stm]</ref>
====Impact on environment==== [[File:Бомбардовање рафинерије нафте Нови Сад.jpeg|thumb|right|Refinery hit by NATO missile.]] [[File:Нато бомбе изазивале еколошку катастрофу у Новом Саду.jpeg|thumb|right|Smoke from bombed Novi Sad's refinery.]] The bombing of Novi Sad had implications for the environment. A United Nations study (the BTF ‘Industrial Sites’ and ‘Danube’ missions) found that there were serious environmental issues, "requiring immediate action", some of which resulted from the bombing.<ref>[http://www.grid.unep.ch/btf/final/finalreport.pdf]</ref> The bombing of Novi Sad's refinery caused fires which burned 50,000 tons of crude oil, sending toxins and [[carcinogen]]s into the air and contaminating groundwater. The BTF study was complicated by the heavy pollution that existed before the bombing, with the group noting that "the enforced shutdown of the refinery may even have led to local improvements in the aquatic environment, due to a possible reduction in chronic pollution".{{ref|BTF}}
Once all the samples for Novi Sad (Danube Mission) were collated, ''"based on field observation and results from sample analysis, the BTF concluded that there was no evidence of significant adverse impacts on the Danube aquatic environment as a result of air strikes on Novi Sad refinery. It is thought that most of the oils and oil products released were burned and that no significant volume entered the river"''.{{ref|BTF}}
The BTF study also found that prior to the air strikes, local technicians helped minimise the potential harmful effects of air strikes by "removing oil products that could be harmful to human health if spilt or burnt, such as transformer oil containing PCBs. Production was also accelerated to use up as much as possible of the crude oil, intermediate products and additives, and the final products were shipped to other locations. The remaining oil was mixed with gasoline, so that the tanks would ignite if hit, rather than leak into the soil and groundwater". {{ref|BTF}}
Local scientists also studied the impact of the bombing. "NATO didn’t use chemical weapons during the bombing", said Dr. Zorka Vukmirović, a leading environmental physicist, "But indirectly it caused the effects of chemical weapons use. If you release so many hazardous substances, major air pollutants and carcinogens in the vicinity of big cities like Belgrade and Niš, it is obviously a deliberate action against the civilian population".<ref>[http://www.commondreams.org/views01/0131-05.htm]</ref>
Not until 2003, the Danube river was declared clear again. It took four years of work by the [[Danube Commission]] to remove the debris of bombed bridges and ordnance.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/3020734.stm]</ref> The clearing of the debris was not only important for Novi Sad, but for European states (Hungary & Romania) who were economically impacted by the blockade of river traffic to the Black sea caused by the bombing.
==The views of the respective parties== {{see also|Legitimacy of the NATO bombing of Yugoslavia}} NATO was accused of committing war crimes due to the nature of some of the bombing raids. Some Novi Sad residents found it ironic that Novi Sad was so heavily targeted by NATO due to the fact that during the time of the bombing, the city was ruled by the local Democratic Opposition, which was against the regime in [[Belgrade]]. Therefore, some citizens of Novi Sad were not able to understand why the city was targeted heavily for the events in [[Kosovo]].
A press release one year on from the bombing by then NATO Secretary General [[George Robertson, Baron Robertson of Port Ellen|Robertson]], claims that [[NATO]] encountered complications from Yugoslav military use of civilian buildings and human shields. NATO officials have "expressed deep regret at any civilian casualties it caused".<ref> [http://www.nato.int/kosovo/repo2000/conduct.htm]</ref>
NATO claims that the bombing of targets such as bridges was aimed at impairing the Yugoslav Army's [[command and control]] structure. However, the efficacy of the campaign and choice of targets was brought into question by human rights groups, after bridges of no conceivable strategic relevance to the military situation in Kosovo were bombed, including a bridge which led to Hungary, a NATO country. MAICL argued{{ref|MAICL}} that the civilian deaths caused were clearly disproportionate to the military benefits in response to NATO's justification of actions.<ref>[http://www.greenparty.org.uk/files/reports/2004/Yugowar%20for%20website.htm]</ref>

{{Other people|Pete Peterson}} {{BLP sources|date=October 2012}} {{Infobox officeholder | name = Pete Peterson | image name = petepeterson.jpg{{!}}border | image_size = 255px | birth_name = Douglas Brian Peterson | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1935|06|26}} | birth_place = [[Omaha, Nebraska]], U.S. | state = [[Florida]] | district = [[Florida's 2nd congressional district|2nd]] | term_start = January 3, 1991 | term_end = January 3, 1997 | preceded = [[James W. Grant|Bill Grant]] | succeeded = [[Allen Boyd]] | office2 = [[List of ambassadors of the United States to Vietnam|Ambassador of the United States of America to the Socialist Republic of Vietnam]] | term_start2 = April 11, 1997 | term_end2 = July 15, 2001 | preceded2=''Inaugural holder'' | succeeded2 = Raymond Burghardt | citizenship=Australian | nationality=American | party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] | allegiance = United States of America | branch ={{Air force|United States|size=23px}} | nickname = "Pete" | serviceyears = 1954–1980 | rank = [[File:US Air Force O6 shoulderboard rotated.svg|25px]] [[Colonel (United States)|Colonel]] | unit = [[433d Weapons Squadron|433rd Tactical Fighter Squadron]] | battles = [[Vietnam War]]{{WIA}} | awards = [[File:Silver Star ribbon.svg|23px|border]] [[Silver Star|Silver Star Medal]]
[[File:Legion of Merit ribbon.svg|23px|border]] [[Legion of Merit]]
[[File:Purple Heart ribbon.svg|23px|border]] [[Purple Heart|Purple Heart Medal]]
[[File:Prisoner of War ribbon.svg|23px|border]] [[Prisoner of War Medal]] }} '''Douglas Brian "Pete" Peterson''' (born June 26, 1935) is an American politician and diplomat. He served as a [[United States Air Force]] pilot during the [[Vietnam War]] and spent over six years as a prisoner of the [[People's Army of Vietnam|North Vietnamese army]] after his plane was shot down. He returned to [[Hanoi]] when he became the first [[List of ambassadors of the United States to Vietnam|United States Ambassador to Vietnam]] in 1997. He was an ambassador until July 2001, after which he devoted himself to philanthropic work. ==Early life and education== Peterson grew up in [[Milton, Iowa]] and attended college at the [[University of Tampa]]. He joined the U.S. Air Force and served in the Vietnam War, where his [[F-4 Phantom II]] fighter was shot down on September 10, 1966. He spent six years in prison, a period he described as "hours and hours of boredom, spliced with moments of stark terror."{{cite news|last=Webb|first=Carolyn|title=POW's journey to Australia, via love in Vietnam |url=http://www.theage.com.au/national/pows-journey-to-australia-via-love-in-vietnam-20090916-frp6.html|accessdate=8 October 2010|newspaper=[[The Age]]|date=17 September 2009}} He was released on March 4, 1973. ==Career== After the Vietnam War, Peterson remained in the U.S. Air Force and retired in 1981 as a colonel with 26 years of service. After retirement he established a general contracting firm in [[Tampa, Florida]] and later a small computer company in [[Marianna, Florida]]. He served for 5 years on the faculty of [[Florida State University]] in [[Tallahassee, Florida]]. In 1990, Peterson ran as a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] for a seat in the [[United States House of Representatives]] in [[Florida's 2nd congressional district]]. He defeated [[James W. Grant]], a politician who grew unpopular after switching from the Democratic Party to the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] in the middle of his second term. He declined to run for a fourth term (he was succeeded by [[Allen Boyd]]) and in 1997 was asked by President [[Bill Clinton]] to become the United States's first post-war ambassador to Vietnam. One of his goals was securing an account of those still listed as missing in action from the war and so helping to resolve the [[Vietnam War POW/MIA issue]]. On November 17, 2000, he was presented with the [[Presidential Citizens Medal]] by President Clinton. ===Philanthropy, business=== Since retiring as ambassador, Peterson founded [[The Alliance for Safe Children]], TASC, which aims to lower preventable injuries to children worldwide, and focuses specifically on such issues as drowning in Asia.{{cite news|title=Children from developing world dying of preventable injuries: UN|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/newsitems/200210/s694479.htm|accessdate=5 October 2010|newspaper=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]|date=6 October 2002}}{{Cite web |title=Pete Peterson: The ex-POW teaching Vietnam to swim |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-21770163 |author=William Kremer |date=23 March 2013 |publisher=BBC News magazine }} With his wife he started a company whose aim it is to promote American business in Southeast Asia.{{cite news|title=Pete Peterson starts business|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ZoUeAAAAIBAJ&sjid=w38EAAAAIBAJ&pg=4396,1567512&dq=pete-peterson+vietnam&hl=en|accessdate=8 October 2010|newspaper=[[Sarasota Herald-Tribune]]|date=27 February 2002}} Peterson is a Senior Advisor for [[Albright Stonebridge Group]], an international strategic consulting firm. ==Personal life== In 1995, his first wife, Carlotta, had died, and two weeks after his installation in [[Hanoi]] he met Vi Le, [[Australia]]'s senior trade commissioner, born in Vietnam, whom he married. In 2002, he moved to [[Melbourne, Australia]] so they could be closer to her family. In 2009, Peterson acquired Australian citizenship. {{-}} ==See also== {{Portal bar|Biography|United States Air Force|Vietnam}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{CongBio|P000259}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080707032851/http://www.aiipowmia.com/inter1/in111800ppc.html All POW-MIA InterNetwork] *{{C-SPAN|Douglas Peterson}} {{S-start}} {{S-par|us-hs}} {{Succession box|before=[[James W. Grant|Bill Grant]] |title=[[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]]
[[Florida's 2nd congressional district]] |years=1991–1997 |after=[[Allen Boyd]]}} {{S-dip}} {{Succession box|before= new office |title=[[List of ambassadors of the United States to Vietnam|United States Ambassador to Vietnam]] |years=April 11, 1997–July 15, 2001 |after=[[Raymond Burghardt]]}} {{S-end}} {{US Ambassadors to Vietnam}} {{U.S. Florida Representatives}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Peterson, Pete}} [[Category:1935 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Members of the United States House of Representatives from Florida]] [[Category:Florida Democrats]] [[Category:Politicians from Omaha, Nebraska]] [[Category:People from Van Buren County, Iowa]] [[Category:University of Tampa alumni]] [[Category:Central Michigan University alumni]] [[Category:Florida State University faculty]] [[Category:United States Air Force colonels]] [[Category:American air force personnel of the Vietnam War]] [[Category:Vietnam War prisoners of war]] [[Category:American prisoners of war]] [[Category:Shot-down aviators]] [[Category:Ambassadors of the United States to Vietnam]] [[Category:American expatriates in Australia]] [[Category:Presidential Citizens Medal recipients]] [[Category:Recipients of the Silver Star]] [[Category:Recipients of the Legion of Merit]] [[Category:Democratic Party members of the United States House of Representatives]]

{{more footnotes|date=December 2013}}
[[File:Ph fashion week logo.jpg|thumb|Official logo of Philippine Fashion Week]] '''Philippine Fashion Week''', (PhFW) is a bi-annual fashion week event held in Manila, Philippines. Dates are determined during the month of May, to showcase Holiday collections (instead of the autumn-winter which does not apply in the country) and again, during the month of October, to showcase Spring and Summer collections. It is the longest running fashion event in the country, and the largest fashion event held in [[Manila]] known as the "Olympics" of Fashion. The Philippine Fashion Week was founded by Joey A. Espino Jr and Audie Espino in 1997. They continue to lead the project as Executive Producers along with Espino brothers protege Conchitina (Tina) Herrera.
Filipino Designers such as [[Arcylen moya]], Ezra Santos, Oliver Tolentino, Albert Andrada, Jerome Salaya Ang, Noel Crisostomo, Jeffrey Rogador, Sidney Perez Sio, EsAc, Pat Santos, Arnold Galang, Roland Alzate, Raoul Ramirez, Lyle Ibanez, Cherry Samuya Veric, Philipp Tampus, Junjun Cambe, Mixy Dy, Jian Lasala, Randall Solomon, Kaye Morales, Boyet Dysangco, Anthony Nocom, Eric Delos Santos, Cesar Gaupo, Robin Tomas, [[Lesley Mobo]], Frederick Peralta, Ben Farrales, [[Pitoy Moreno]] and Aureo Alonzo have presented full collections on Philippine Fashion Week's dynamic Multi-Media platform. The Philippine Fashion Week is ‘by invitation only’ and participating designers pay a participation fee with each designer undergoing a stringent selection process with their collections approved on the basis of their design ingenuity.
Each season, Philippine Fashion Week generates extensive media coverage reaching an average audience of five million viewers, followers and fashion fans throughout the world.
As of 2008 it is being held at the [[SMX Convention Center]] & [[SM Mall of Asia]] and welcomed more designers and local brands to take part in the Bi Annual Event.
Some of the notable celebrities and personalities gracing the runways of Philippine Fashion Week include Nina Garcia of ''[[Project Runway]]'' US, ''[[Gossip Girl]]''<nowiki/>'s [[Leighton Meester]], ''[[Keeping Up with the Kardashians]]''<nowiki/>' [[Rob Kardashian]] and [[Kylie Jenner]], British supermodel [[David Gandy]], ''[[America's Next Top Model]]''<nowiki/>'s [[Allison Harvard]] and [[Dominique Reighard]], [[Ford Models]]' Katie Ford and the Miss Shapes to name a few. International Filipino supermodels [[Charo Ronquillo]], [[Charlene Almarvez]], Danica Magpantay, Manuela Basilio and Paolo Roldan also return home to walk the runways.
Philippine Fashion Week continues discover, nurture and showcase the new generation designers who have gone on to conquer the world of fashion and attain global recognition worn by celebrities including [[Beyoncé]], [[Rihanna]], [[Lady Gaga]], [[Sofía Vergara]], [[Christina Aguilera]], [[Nicole Scherzinger]], [[Jennifer Lopez]], [[Chris Brown]], [[Britney Spears]], [[Fergie (singer)|Fergie]], [[Tyra Banks]], [[Paula Patton]], [[Paris Hilton]], [[Dita Von Teese]], [[Emmy Rossum]] and [[Mischa Barton]].
[[File:Top Model All Stars Dominique Reighard and Allison Harvard.jpg|thumb|[[America's Next Top Model: All-Stars]] walks down the runway at the Spring-Summer Fashion Week in 2012]]
== Sponsorship == Philippine Fashion Week is annually presented by Runway Productions, CalCarries, EsAC and Masters School for Models. In previous seasons Philippine Fashion Week was sponsored MasterCard, L'Oreal Paris, Maybelline New York, Power Mac Center, Beats by Dre, Moshi, Gosh, Knomo London, [[Happy Plugs]] Stockholm, CaseMate, BDO, SM Residences, Hamilo Coast, Pico de Loro Club, Ipanema, Sony Vaio, Sony Cybershot, PLDT, Axe, Ponds, Sunsilk, Cream Silk, Magnum Ice Cream, Nestle, Emperador and Cignal TV to name a few.
The government sector has also turned to the runways of Philippine Fashion Week to shine the spotlight on local fabric and craftsmanship including Department of Agriculture, Fiber Industry Development Authority and Burdang Taal collaborating with Filipino Designers for each respective collection.
Other special presentations on the runways of Philippine Fashion Week include SM Department Store's 50th Anniversary Celebration, A tribute to Louie Mamengo, A tribute to Joe Salazar, Salvacion Lim Higgins Slim's at 50, Project Runway Philippines Finale Season 1 and Season 2, Ford Supermodel of the World Philippines, and Supermodel Philippines.
== Brands == Participating brands in the recent years have grown from SM Store's SM Woman, SM Men, SM Kids, SM Shoes & Bags, Parisian, Forever 21, Alexander Wang X H&M, The Ramp- Crossings Department Store, Rusty Lopez, Bench, Human, Kashieca, Freego, FG, Wrangler, Giordano, Vans, Guess, Levi's, Lee Jeans, Jag Jeans, Candie's, Folded & Hung, Triumph, Wharton, Jelly Bean, Bayo, Plains & Prints, Petit Monde, Barbie 50th Anniversary, Penshoppe, Oxygen, Regatta, Memo, For Me, Avon Fashion, Unica Hija, Sfera, Suite Blanco, Uno de 50, Mint gather to showcase their collection each season.
== Early 2000's == Philippine Fashion Week was previously held at Glorietta Activity Center with offsite shows, parties and activities at the NBC Tent, The Rockwell Tent, InterContinental Manila and Shangri-la Makati. Its early years saw the participation of mostly international fashion brands entering the Philippine market and group show designers presenting capsule collections that took place for 7–10 days once a year.
Today the Philippine Fashion Week is held at venues like the SMX Convention Center, SM Mall of Asia Arena, SM Mall of Asia, SM Aura with off-site activities at the Peninsula Hotel Manila and Raven Boutique Club.
==See also== * [[Fashion Week]] * [[Runway (fashion)|Runway Fashion]] * [[Pasay|City of Pasay]]

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contributions/71.87.25.226|71.87.25.226]] ([[User talk:71.87.25.226|talk]]) ([[WP:HG|HG]]) (3.4.4)
revision.text:
{{about||the 2006 M. Ward album|Post-War|the 2005 Tony Judt book|Postwar (book)}} [[Image:Frenchciviliansburon.jpg|thumb|right|275px|A French family returns to their village, [[Buron]], northwest of [[Caen]], which was completely destroyed [[Battle for Caen|during fighting]], July 18, 1944]]
A '''post-war period''' or '''postwar period''' is the interval immediately following the end of a [[war]]. A post-war period can become an [[interwar period]] or [[interbellum]], when a war between the same parties resumes at a later date (e.g., the period between [[World War I]] and [[World War II]]). By contrast, a post-war period marks the cessation of conflict entirely.
In [[Western world|Western]] usage, references to the '''post-war era''' or '''postwar era''' (sometimes capitalized) usually refer to the time since the end of [[World War II]], although many nations involved in the Second World War have been involved in wars since.
==Post-war==
===Chronology of the post–World War II era===
The term "post-war" can have different meanings in different countries and refer to a period determined by local considerations based on the effect of the war there. In Britain, "post-war" refers to the period from the election of [[Clement Attlee]] in 1945 to that of [[Margaret Thatcher]] in 1979, a period of so-called [[post-war consensus]], while it may also refer to a shorter period, ending in 1960 or shortly after and corresponding to the 1950s era, hence 1945–1960.<ref>[http://www.worthpoint.com/worthopedia/aec-lorries-post-war-years-1945-1979-248690820 AEC Lorries in the post war years 1945–1979 book (09/10/2011)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~weterb/The%20Post.htm The Post-War Years 1945 – 1960<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://economics.about.com/od/useconomichistory/a/post_war.htm The Post War Economy: 1945–1960<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
===Cold War era=== Considering the post-war era as equivalent to the [[Cold War]] era, post-war sometimes includes the 1980s, putting the end at December 1991, with the [[Dissolution of the Soviet Union]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.letsgo.com/12350-europe-travel-guides-the_netherlands-history-c |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-06-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110822122321/http://www.letsgo.com/12350-europe-travel-guides-the_netherlands-history-c |archivedate=2011-08-22 |df= }}</ref><ref>[http://soapbox.websitetoolbox.com/post?id=2019573 Charting Europe's Future in the 'Post Postwar' Era. - Soap Box Discussion Forums and Messageboard - Home of the Patrioteer<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The 1990s and the 21st century are rarely considered to be part of the post-war era.
==See also== * [[Interwar period]] * [[Aftermath of the September 11 attacks]] * [[Postbellum (disambiguation)|Postbellum]] * [[Pre-war (disambiguation)|Pre-war]] * [[Reconstruction Era]] of the U.S.
==References== {{reflist}} {{wiktionary}}

revision.text:
[[File:Queen's Theatre, Adelaide.JPG|thumb|Queen's Theatre, Playhouse Lane]]
The '''Queen's Theatre''' is a building of historic importance in Playhouse Lane, [[Adelaide]], South Australia. It is the oldest intact theatre in mainland Australia, but was predated by [[Theatre Royal, Hobart|Theatre Royal]] in Hobart, Tasmania.<ref name="Illustrated">{{cite book |title= Heritage of the City of Adelaide: an illustrated guide |publisher= Corporation of the [[City of Adelaide]] and the [[National Library of Australia]] |year=1989 |first1= Susan |first2=Paul |first3= Patricia |last1= Marsden |last2= Stark |last3= Sumerling |isbn=0-909866-30-9}}</ref> It was not the first theatre in Adelaide however, that being Samson Cameron's short-lived Royal Victoria Theatre on North Terrace <!--a converted warehouse behind where the Black Bull hotel later stood-->which opened on 23 November 1839.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article27440983 |title= Royal Victoria Theatre |newspaper=[[South Australian Register]] |location= Adelaide |date= 16 November 1839 |accessdate= 10 August 2012 |page=3 |publisher= National Library of Australia}}</ref>
==History== By the early 1800s, live performance was increasing in popularity in Australia, although no entertainment venues existed to house performances. In the 1830s, both [[Sydney]] and [[Hobart]] received two theatres, the first in the Australian colonies.<ref name="Illustrated" />
Only four years following settlement of South Australia in 1836, attempts to build a substantial theatre in an increasingly prosperous Adelaide were made, with a declaration by the ''South Australian Register'' stating "...Mr Solomon, of Currie Street, is about to make an important addition to the quarter of Gilles Arcade, by the erection of a spacious and handsome edifice which he ends to fit up as a theatre".<ref name="Illustrated" /> It was built for [[Emanuel Solomon]] (1800–1873) and his Sydney-based brother [[Vaiben Solomon]] (1802–1860)<ref>Two of Vaiben's brothers lived in Adelaide: Emanuel and Isaac. The famous [[Vaiben Louis Solomon]] and [[Judah Moss Solomon]] were of the following generation.</ref> in 1840<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article27441265 |title=Gilles Arcade |newspaper=[[South Australian Register]] |location=Adelaide |date=14 March 1840 |accessdate=10 August 2012 |page=4 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> for £3000<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/south-australia/finds-from-the-19th-century-in-archaeological-dig-at-old-queens-theatre-to-be-handed-to-sa-museum/news-story/44f23c33f955b28dda66935136ee98ac?login=1|title=Adelaidenow.com.au {{!}} Subscribe to The Advertiser for exclusive stories|website=www.adelaidenow.com.au|language=en|access-date=2018-04-07}}</ref> with seating for over 1000 people<ref name="Mail">{{cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article55729046|title=Our Notable Pioneers|date=7 November 1936|newspaper=[[The Mail (Adelaide)|The Mail]]|accessdate=8 August 2012|publisher=National Library of Australia|location=Adelaide|page=4 Section: Magazine}}</ref>. The project had dire predictions of failure from the press<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71620577 |title=The Queen's Theatre |newspaper=[[Southern Australian]] |location=Adelaide |date=29 December 1840 |accessdate=8 August 2012 |page=3 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> and opened with ''[[Othello]]'' on 11 January 1841,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article36851960 |title=The Queen's Theatre |newspaper=[[The Australian (1824 newspaper)|The Australian]] |location=Sydney |date=28 January 1841 |accessdate=8 August 2012 |page=2 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> the manager [[John Lazar]] in the title role, to "mixed reviews".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article195860485 |title=The Queen's Theatre |newspaper=[[Adelaide Chronicle And South Australian Literary Record]] |volume=II, |issue=LVIII |location=South Australia |date=13 January 1841 |accessdate=18 June 2017 |page=3 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> The Southern Australian's prognostications proved correct. Public appetite for entertainment had waned with the Depression brought on by [[Governor Grey]]'s fiscally responsible regime following the prosperity of [[Governor Gawler]]'s rule, when huge sums were invested in public infrastructure. After months of losing money, Lazar dismissed his company and converted the seating to something more appropriate to public meetings,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71615222 |title=Theatricals in Adelaide |newspaper=[[Southern Australian]] |volume=IV, |issue=237 |location=South Australia |date=27 August 1841 |accessdate=18 June 2017 |page=2 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> and some use was made of the theatre for public meetings and lectures, but did not renew his lease.
Solomon offered the government use of the theatre ''gratis'' if they would prohibit the building of further taverns in the vicinity (his Shakspere Tavern,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article50246683 |title=Advertising. |newspaper=[[South Australian Register]] |location=Adelaide |date=7 February 1849 |accessdate=10 August 2012 |page=2 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> subsequently named Temple Tavern, was adjacent). This was rejected, but in 1843 the government signed a contract with Solomon for three years' rental at £200 per annum for use as Resident Magistrates Court, Supreme Court and offices for the Registrar General, the Advocate General, the Assistant Crown Solicitor and Assistant to the Bench of Magistrates.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article37115150 |title=South Australia |newspaper=[[The Australian (1824 newspaper)|The Australian]] |location=Sydney |date=24 July 1843 |accessdate=8 August 2012 |page=3 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
Between 1846 and 1847 Solomon, whose nephew [[Judah Moss Solomon]] (1818–1880) was an occasional partner, attempted to sell the theatre and tavern by lottery, but it was never fully subscribed so he refunded to the punters their stakes.
It reopened, re-using the name '''Royal Victoria Theatre''', under the management of [[John Lazar]] and [[George Coppin]], on 23 December 1850.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article38437326 |title=The Theatre |newspaper=[[South Australian Register]] |location=Adelaide |date=24 December 1850 |accessdate=9 August 2012 |page=3 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
In 1861 it closed for refurbishment and substantial remodelling, and reopened in July with A. J. Solomon the new lessee and Robert MacGowan the stage manager<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article50084507 |title=Victoria Theatre |newspaper=[[South Australian Register]] |location=Adelaide |date=15 July 1861 |accessdate=30 August 2012 |page=3 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> of what was Adelaide's only theatre until the opening of the Theatre Royal at 28 [[Hindley Street, Adelaide|Hindley Street]] on 13 April 1868,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article55153409 |title=Old-Time Theatres |newspaper=[[The Register (Adelaide)|The Register]] |location=Adelaide |date=6 January 1921 |accessdate=9 August 2012 |page=5 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> which spelled the demise of the "Victoria".
It then became successively a dance hall designated the "Prado",<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article39198678 |title=The Dancing Saloons and Night-Houses |newspaper=[[South Australian Register]] |location=Adelaide |date=28 June 1870 |accessdate=9 August 2012 |page=6 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> the headquarters for the [[Mission Australia|City Mission]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article39264368 |title=The City Mission |newspaper=[[South Australian Register]] |location=Adelaide |date=15 August 1872 |accessdate=9 August 2012 |page=4 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> a horse market<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article56073135 |title=Early Experiences on South Australia |newspaper=[[The Register (Adelaide)|The Register]] |location=Adelaide |date=27 March 1901 |accessdate=9 August 2012 |page=7 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> and other commercial uses, and finally a car park.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article57055963 |title=Gilles Arcade |newspaper=[[The Register (Adelaide)|The Register]] |location=Adelaide |date=14 July 1928 |accessdate=9 August 2012 |page=13 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
===Recent development=== [[File:Queen's Theatre, Adelaide, interior.JPG|thumb|The partially restored interior, now used as a performance space, during a History Month tour in 2014]] The building was purchased by the South Australian Asset Management Corporation and transferred to Heritage SA in the 1980s. Excavation revealed historically significant remains and numerous artefacts.
The Queen's Theatre was reopened as a performance venue at the 1996 Adelaide Festival of Arts, with a performance of [[The Magic Flute]] by [[Opera Australia]]. Following essential refurbishments, it was reopened for the launch of the 1998 Festival of Arts by [[Robyn Archer]].<ref>[http://www.liveguide.com.au/Venues/6518/Queens_Theatre Queens Theatre in Adelaide, SA]</ref>
The theatre is now used as a performance space and function venue, but with stringent conditions intended to preserve as far as possible, the old character of the building.<ref>[http://www.yelp.com.au/biz/queens-theatre-adelaide Queen's Theatre – Adelaide South Australia]</ref>. The Queen’s Theatre is now managed by GWB McFarlane Theatres.<ref>[http://www.queenstheatre.com.au/contact/ GWB McFarlane Theatres] Retrieved 30 October 2018.</ref>.
==New Queen's Theatre== A new theatre was built in 1846 for [[George Coppin]] on nearby land on [[Light Square]] belonging to Solomon and managed by John Lazar, architect one Thomas Price.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article158923388 |title=Our Colonial Review |newspaper=[[Adelaide Observer]] |volume=IV, |issue=176 |location=South Australia |date=7 November 1846 |accessdate=10 February 2018 |page=4 |via=National Library of Australia}} Price, active 1845–50, had offices in Hindley Street</ref> The hall held 700 and had the distinction of prohibiting smoking in the [[box (theatre)|boxes]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71606193 |title=Advertising. |newspaper=[[The South Australian]] |location=Adelaide |date=23 October 1846 |access-date=8 August 2012 |page=2 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> In January 1850, the New Queen's Theatre was described by the ''[[South Australian Register]]'' as "a hotbed of demoralization" and that "no man can sit out a performance without being disgusted ; no lady can enter the impure precincts without contamination".<ref>{{cite news | url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/38438554/3932001 | title=A Licentious Stage | newspaper=[[South Australian Register]] | date=16 January 1850}}</ref> This article was the occasion of a successful libel case against editor [[John Stephens (editor)|John Stephens]] in March 1850.<ref> {{cite news | url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/page/18836185 | title= Law and Police Courts : Lazar vs Stephens | newspaper=[[Adelaide Observer]] | date=9 March 1850}}</ref> The [[Adelaide Garrick Club]]<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article38438426 |title=Local Intelligence |newspaper=[[South Australian Register]] |volume=XIV, |issue=1068 |location=South Australia |date=14 March 1850 |accessdate=19 February 2017 |page=2 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> may have been the last company to mount plays there, with productions of three [[Thomas Morton (playwright)|Thomas Morton]] comedies, the last in September 1850. There is no newspaper reference to this theatre after November 1850.
== References == {{Reflist}}
===Bibliography=== *{{cite book|author=West, John |title=Theatre in Australia |publisher=Cassell Australia |year=1978 |isbn=0-7269-9266-6}}
